{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29377117389","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STREAMING MEDIA","domains":["IND"],"score":"88"},{"name":"BROADCAST ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"66"},{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"TELEVISION ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"SPORTS MARKETING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FILM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"MARKETING & ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ACTORS & ACTRESSES","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MARKETING & ADVERTISING AGENCIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DATA PROCESSING SERVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"AMERICAN FOOTBALL; SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CELEBRITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NORTHEAST USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"ATLANTA, GA, USA; UNITED STATES; GEORGIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"56"},{"name":"ADAM DRIVER","domains":["PEO"],"score":"76"}],"wordCount":"700","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396193337&p=2kx&v=1&x=C1CBs9798HaDOcQRlSZDig","id":"29396193337","content":"NEW YORK - Lady Gaga is reportedly entertaining an unusual twist on her Super Bowl halftime show, which - though it's not confirmed - she could perform from the roof of the stadium. If that comes to pass, she won't be the only one making a big play for attention this year. \n \nAdvertisers from first-timer 84 Lumber to veteran Hyundai are ramping up the marketing stunts in order to stand out from the crowd during the big game. Some will air live ads, or at least teasers for their campaigns; one will even shoot its commercial during the game. Others are deliberately courting controversy. \n \nSuper Bowl LI, in which the Atlanta Falcons will take on the New England Patriots, is expected to be the biggest live TV event of the year. \n \nThe war for attention \n \nEvery year, more than 30 advertisers vie to create the most-remembered 30 to 90 seconds of the Super Bowl by stuffing commercials with celebrities, slapstick humor and cute animals. \n \nBut now that so many ads get pre-released online or teased ahead of the game, advertisers have a harder time making a lasting impression. And with more than 110 million people expected to tune in on Feb. 5 and 30-second spots going for around $5 million, they need to scramble hard. \n \nSo this year, marketers are turning to stunts. \n \n\"It used to be, 'We need a Super Bowl spot.' Then, it was, 'We need a Super Bowl spot and program,' \" said Mark DiMassimo, CEO of ad agency DiMassimo Goldstein in New York. \"Now, it's 'We need a Super Bowl stunt or event. It needs to be newsworthy, social and surprising - and it needs to be much bigger than 30 seconds.' \" \n \nGoing live \n \nSnickers said Wednesday it will air a live Super Bowl ad in the third quarter starring Adam Driver (\"Star Wars: The Force Awakens\"). The Mars brand will also live-stream the set of the commercial for 36 hours ahead of the spot. \n \n\"The actual ad is only part of the equation,\" said Allison Miazga-Bedrick, a Snickers brand director, who promises \"over 30 hours of original content\" streamed live leading up to the game. \n \nSimilarly, Wix - an Israeli website hosting service- turned to Facebook Live and YouTube Live on Jan. 17 to debut teasers for its Super Bowl ad. The teaser - which was prerecorded and only streamed live - starred Israeli actress and model Gal Gadot, who plays Wonder Woman in her own film later this year, and the English actor Jason Statham (\"The Fast and the Furious\"). \n \nThe company said it's the first time a Super Bowl campaign has been launched live. \n \nBetting on rejection \n \nFirst-time Super Bowl advertiser 84 Lumber pulled a vintage ad stunt when the company went public with claims that Fox rejected its original ad because it was too \"controversial.\" \n \nThe Pennsylvania building materials supplier bought a 90-second ad during the game - a huge commitment for a regional brand. But Amy Smiley, the company's director of marketing, said its first ad was rejected because some of its imagery, including a border wall that supposedly prevented people from working in the U.S., steered too close to political rhetoric about the Mexican border from President Donald Trump. \n \nFox declined to comment, ensuring that 84 Lumber got plenty of press well ahead of the game. \n \nShooting on the fly \n \nIn perhaps the biggest gamble, Hyundai is teaming with director Peter Berg (\"Deepwater Horizon\") to actually film a 90-second ad while the Super Bowl is underway. Hyundai said the ad will show \"off the field\" moments captured during the game, and will air right after the contest ends. \n \nTraditionally, ads that air before or after the Super Bowl itself aren't very successful at drawing eyeballs. But the on-the-fly aspect of this ad could make it hard to ignore. \n \n\"The challenge for all of these companies is, 'How do you stand out?' \" said Tim Calkins, a marketing professor at Northwestern University. \"As a result, we're going to see this year people try some very curious approaches.\" \n \nDean Evans, Hyundai's chief marketing officer, said the shoot-during-the-game approach is all about buzz. \n \n\"We wanted to test ourselves,\" Evans said. \"We thought we would have to do it in a new and nontraditional way to really show the U.S. public that we're back in the game.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"MAE ANDERSON Of The"},"topics":[{"name":"Hyundai Motor Company news","group":"Companies"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: American football news","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Super Bowl ads are going for stunts","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204311798","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:16Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/lmtribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/1d/b1df03ff-8c23-5960-b6bf-c7662479bbc4/588bdf4784461.image.jpg?resize=300%2C230"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"sub","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:16Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396182144","companies":[{"symbol":"GTR","primary":true,"name":"Global Trade SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"WAR","titleCount":0,"isin":"PLGLBLT00015"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"WORLD WAR I","domains":["SUB"],"score":"61"},{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GLOBALIZATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"WRITERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"BREXIT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"BUDDHISTS & BUDDHISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"JEWS & JUDAISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TRENDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERVIEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SOCIOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"TEHRAN, IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF; IRAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"746","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396193338&p=2kx&v=1&x=_JUuw6UgPCbSONctmxZSxw","id":"29396193338","content":"Interview by Mohammad Mazhari \n \nTEHRAN, Jan. 29 (MNA) \u2013 Trump\u2019s election to presidency in the US, his clear stand against global trade, and his persistence on American indigenous potentials have challenged theory of globalization. \n \nTrump has pointed out to \u2018America First\u2019 policy and tries to protect American market from Chinese goods. In the same context, some experts consider Brexit and rise of right-wing parties in Europe as a failure of process of globalization and rise of a sort of \u2018deglobalization\u2019 which highlights national and local values and cultures. \n \nTo address the diverse dimensions of this subject, we reached George Ritzer, distinguished University of Maryland professor. Ritzer is well-known for Iranian students for his books on sociological theories. \n \nAmong his books in theory are Sociology: A Multiple Paradigm Science (1975/1980) and Metatheorzing in Sociology (1991). In the application of social theory to the social world, his books include The McDonaldization of Society (7th ed., 2013), Enchanting a Disenchanted World (3rd ed. 2010), and The Globalization of Nothing (2nd ed., 2007). His is also the author of Globalization: A Basic Text (Blackwell, 2010).  He edited the Wiley-Blackwell Companion to Sociology (2012), The Blackwell Companion to Globalization (2008) and co-edited the Wiley-Blackwell Companions to Classical and Contemporary Major Social Theorists (2012) and the Sage Handbook of Social Theory (2001). \n \nHere is our interview with him: \n \nHow do you see the relationship between \u201cnationalism\u201d and \u2018globalization\u2019? Would you consider \u2018nationalism\u2019 as a major obstacle for the process of \u2018globalization\u2019? \n \nAs in all things, it is complicated. For example, there can be a positive relationship between them as, for example, in the global trend toward increased nationalism during WW I and II. There could also be a negative relationship as in the global trend away from nationalism after those wars and their disastrous effects. At the moment, of course, the trend toward nationalism is serving as an obstacle to globalization. But these things are dialectical and sooner or later the pendulum will swing back. \n \nCan we see Trump\u2019s election to presidency, UK withdrawal from EU and rise of right-wing parties in Europe as a failure for process of globalization? Or it\u2019s better to regard them as temporary phenomena? \n \nAs implied in the answer to question 1, it is temporary (of course, temporary could last years or even decades). I don\u2019t think it\u2019s a \u201cfailure\u201d of globalization, but rather another moment in its ebb and flow. \n \nWhat is the role of religion in the globalization process, given that religions such as Christianity and Islam claim universal values; can we suppose the religion as rival for globalization? \n \nNo, religion is one of the most important globalizing forces both historically and contemporaneously. Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Judaism, and others have globalized and have had a wide-scale impact on the world. I think you are assuming, as most people do, that globalization equals economic globalization, but from my point of view it is one of a number of aspects of globalization (this communication between us is another minor example) \n \nSome countries and cultures resist against globalization, justifying their resistance by the premise that it would devastate cultural diversity in our world; instead, they put emphasis on local values and cultures. Would you think that the localization is a barrier to globalization? Or it can enrich our world and globalization process? \n \nBoth! Localization is a barrier to many forms of globalization and in that sense can be a barrier to the enrichments associated with globalization. On the other hand, the local is a source of great diversity and much of that can be, and has been, globalized. Of course, the exclusionary power of the local can limit or eliminate the spread of that diversity. \n \nDoes globalization equal westernization or Americanization? Or you recognize a model of multipolar world which includes China, Europe and Islamic-Arabic countries? \n \nNo, but they have been the most powerful globalizing forces in the last two centuries. With their decline we will have an increasingly multipolar world. China will be an increasingly important globalizing force, especially economically, in the years to come. Europe is part of the west, but its independent influence on globalization is declining with the problems in the EU. At the moment, at least under Trump, the U.S. is opting for a smaller role globally. Islam has had a powerful effect historically and to this day. Unfortunately, its positive influence today has been obscured by the tendency, at least in much of the West, to associate it, or at least its more radical elements, with terrorism. \n \nYou can also read the interview in ARABIC.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Asia-Pacific latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"China news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"China rising globalizing force thanks...","source":{"category":"Organisation","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"South-Eastern Asia","countryCode":"ID","country":"Indonesia"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Organization of Asia-Pacific News Agencies","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169667991","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"10"},"name":"Organization of Asia-Pacific News Agencies","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Organisations"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.oananews.org"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204311963","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:16Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"1304","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396193466&p=2kx&v=1&x=YTAbW5Ad4uIskDamgBc8Iw","id":"29396193466","content":"TEHRAN, Jan. 29 (MNA) \u2013 Canadian Human Rights Attorney Edward Corrigan rejected the \u2018muted\u2019 protests of the United States, Great Britain and other Western powers against the human rights violation in Bahrain as appalling. \n\nBahrain\u2019s human rights climate remains highly problematic. The country\u2019s courts convict and imprison peaceful dissenters and have failed to hold officials accountable for torture and other serious rights violations. \n\nEdward Corrigan said Western countries are more concerned about their strategic alliance with the Al-Khalifa regime than about human rights or the wishes of the majority of the population in Bahrain. \n\nHe warned if the population of Bahrain explodes in anger over the repression and discriminatory treatment, it will put in jeopardy the presence of the United States and Britain, given their long history of support for the Al-Khalifa dictatorship. \n\n\u201cStrategic relationship with the Al-Khalifa regime is due to its strategic location of Bahrain which allows the United States and Britain to project their power in the Persian Gulf area,\u201d Corrigan noted in an exclusive interview with Mehr News Agency: \n\nWhat is the outcome of Bahraini government\u2019s suppression of pro-democracy activists? How do you evaluate the role of international community in countering the crimes and torture in Bahrain? \n\nThe brutal repression of peaceful marchers who are protesting the execution by firing squad of the three young activists is only going to intensify the resistance to the Al-Khalifa regime. If the regime does not allow peaceful protest and recognize the right to free speech and address the concerns of the majority Shia population there will be more violence. If one suppresses peaceful protest then it makes it inevitable that violent protest will result if there is no other alternative. \n\nIn September 2016 in a joint statement signed by 35 countries, the UN Human Rights Council expressed serious concern about human rights violations in Bahrain including imprisonment of those exercising their rights to freedom of expression, assembly and association, and lack of accountability. \n\nIn response to the executions the international community has been more vocal in their criticism. The United Nations Human Rights Commissioner issued a harsh rebuke saying that it was appalled by the executions. The UN Commission said they had \u201cserious doubts whether the accused were provided with the right to have a fair trial.\u201d \n\nThe UN Committee was extremely critical of the trials and executions. In a Press Release they wrote: \u201cWe are appalled at the execution by firing squad of three men in Bahrain on Sunday. The men had been convicted of a bombing in Manama in 2014 that killed three police officers. They were found guilty after being allegedly tortured into making false confessions and their lawyers were not given access to all the evidence against them nor allowed to cross-examine prosecution witnesses during court hearings.\u201d \n\nThey were joined by the United States who said they were \u201cconcerned\u201d about the executions. France also condemned the executions. Great Britain and the European Union deplored the use of the death penalty in this situation. Many other countries including Iran, and Iraq strongly condemned the executions of what they called \u201cpolitical\u201d prisoners. \n\nHere is what Human Rights Watch wrote about the trials: \u201cThe UN Human Rights Committee, which interprets the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Bahrain has ratified, has said that \u201cin cases of trials leading to the imposition of the death penalty scrupulous respect of the guarantees of fair trial is particularly important and that any death penalty imposed after an unfair trial would be a violation of the right to life. Human Rights Watch opposes the death penalty in all circumstances because of its inherent cruelty.\u201d \n\nAmnesty International has made similar criticism of the trials and called them \u201cunfair\u201d and they noted that the confessions were based on torture. The trials did not meet the required international standards. \n\nHow do you analyze the role of other countries, including US and UK, in raising tensions in Bahrain resulting in human rights abuses? \n\nThe muted protests of the United States, Great Britain and other Western powers is appalling. They are more concerned about their strategic alliance with the Al-Khalifa regime than about human rights or the wishes of the majority of the population in Bahrain. Britain has a military presence in Bahrain which they wish to protect. The United States 5th Fleet is based in Bahrain. The Americans also provide other support. In June 2016, the US government lifted its embargo on arms sales to the Bahrain National Guard and Bahrain Defense Forces. In August 2016 approved an US$150 million deal to supply military aircraft parts, ammunition and communications equipment to Bahrain. These actions reward the Manama regime for its violation of human and political rights. \n\nIf the population of Bahrain explodes in anger over the repression and discriminatory treatment, it will put in jeopardy the presence of the United States and Britain, given their long history of support for the Al-Khalifa dictatorship. \n\nWhy human rights pretenders like the US and UK not only are silent against Bahraini government curtailing freedoms of expression, association and assembly and cracking down on dissent, but also provide the country with financial aids? \n\nAgain it is the perceived \u201cstrategic relationship\u201d with the Al-Khalifa regime and the strategic location of Bahrain which allows the United States and Britain to project their power in the Persian Gulf area that dominates the thinking of the Western Powers. The importance of oil and the ongoing support of the British, and now the Americans, for the monarchical dictatorships in the Persian Gulf region necessitates a military presence to prop up the autocratic feudal regimes in the area. There is a realization on the part of the West that if they did not support the Persian Gulf States with weapons, money and military force if needed, these regimes would collapse given their precarious nature. \n\nDo you think the Conflict, Stability and Security Fund (CSSF)- a financial pool worth more than £1bn a year- is evidence of the militarization of Britain\u2019s development budget and UK complicity in abuses? \n\nYes. This budget is largely without oversight and is controlled by the Conservative British government at the present time. There has been funding to Bahrain in the amount of two million pounds. It does appear that this fund is being used to support dictatorships and not development. \n\nMany activists, NGOs and Human rights campaigners in Bahrain, like the Labor party in Britain, complain about the lack of transparency surrounding how the reserves are spent and about a high degree of ambiguity about the status of the CSSF fund. What do you think about this? \n\nThis money is reportedly to help Bahrain to improve its justice system and to improve human rights in the tiny Persian Gulf monarchy. However, as critics have pointed out that the justice system in Bahrain is getting much worse. Torture is being used against prisoners and being used to convict activists with some receiving the death sentence. In addition there is violent suppression of peaceful demonstrators, the killing of unarmed demonstrators and the revocation of citizenship from more than 200 Bahrainis. Freedom of speech and political rights are under severe attack in Bahrain. There have been calls in Britain by the Labor Opposition and by human rights groups to stop sending money to Bahrain until the Al-Khalifa regime substantially improves its human rights record. This money should be used to improve human rights and not to reward human rights abusers. \n\nEdward C. Corrigan holds a B.A. in History and a Master\u2019s Degree in Political Science from the University of Western Ontario. He also has a Law Degree from the University of Windsor and was called to the Bar of the Law Society of Upper Canada in 1992. His academic area of expertise is the Middle East and he has published many articles in academic publications including Middle East Policy, Middle East International, Outlook and Z Magazine.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Bahrain news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Support for Al-Khalifa, Western strategy to project power in Persian Gulf","source":{"category":"Organisation","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"South-Eastern Asia","countryCode":"ID","country":"Indonesia"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Organization of Asia-Pacific News Agencies","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169667991","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"10"},"name":"Organization of Asia-Pacific News Agencies","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Organisations"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.oananews.org"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204314572","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:18Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The loss is a calculation of revenue and expenses at the port's container dock, a large warehouse, its rentals and a telecommunications network it is constructing, according to the port's annual audit. \n \nOne of the largest expenses was depreciation at $406,469, which has to be deducted as infrastructure ages, but is not real dollars going out the door. \n \nThe port experienced losses in the same category of $92,435 in fiscal year 2013, $445,497 in fiscal year 2014 and $401,917 in fiscal year 2015. \n \nPort officials contend the losses are not an accurate picture of the port's overall financial health. \n \nThe port's net position was $24.3 million at the end of fiscal year 2016 and $21.9 million at the end of fiscal year 2013. \n \nThat number includes the port's capital assets, which were $19.6 million in fiscal year 2016 and $17.3 million in fiscal year 2013, according to an email from port Manager David Doeringsfeld. \n \nIt also contains the more than $400,000 the port receives each year in property taxes and more than $1 million in gains from property sales. \n \nThe port used to ship dried peas and lentils from its container dock until the overseas carriers that took them to their final destinations stopped calling on the Port of Portland. That service is expected to resume in the future, but it is \"unlikely\" to return during the present fiscal year, according to the audit. Plenty of cargo still originates in Lewiston at the Lewis Clark Terminal that handles bulk agricultural commodities. \n \nSt. Joseph Regional Medical Center: No deal yet \n \nThe wait to see what will happen to the area's largest hospital continues. \n \nThe Idaho Attorney General's Office received a two-month extension to finish its review of the matter, citing a need for more time to obtain information such as the due diligence St. Joseph Regional Medical Center completed in selecting a buyer. The decision had been due on Jan. 18. It now can be issued as late as March 20. \n \nRCCH Regional Healthcare Partners in Brentwood, Tenn., is poised to acquire St. Joe's from Ascension in a $109 million deal. \n \nThe would-be buyer is part of the investment firm, Apollo Global Management, and operates a network of 17 regional health care systems in other areas. Ascension is based in St. Louis. It is the largest not-for-profit health system in the United States and the biggest Catholic medical organization in the world. \n \n57 channels and no FOX on \n \nA notice about an ongoing dispute is all Cable One viewers see when they turn on KAYU-FOX. The cable company that serves the Lewiston-Clarkston Valley and the owner of the Spokane network affiliate don't see eye to eye on a retransmission agreement. (See accompanying stories.) The standoff shocked many Cable One customers. It started on New Year's Day and prevented many viewers from seeing the Seattle Seahawks beat the San Francisco 49ers in a regular-season finale aired on KAYU-FOX. \n \nA new face for Thunder Jet \n \nBrunswick didn't skimp on talent when it chose a leader for its recent Clarkston acquisition, Thunder Jet. Erik Bon Fleur, an engineer who's completing his master's in administration, is in charge of the operations, which employ close to 100. Brunswick, a multinational company with 16,000 employees, intends to keep all of the Thunder Jet operations in Clarkston, where it is renovating and expanding. Thunder Jet provided Brunswick an entrance into the heavy-gauge welded aluminum boat market, a sector that serves those who pilot boats in tough conditions such as whitewater and the ocean. \n \nMore hamburgers anyone? \n \nHamburgers are one of the foods diners order most when they go out to eat. Lewiston-Clarkston Valley residents will have another place to score them this spring. \n \nZip's Drive-In is replacing Polar Bear, one of Lewiston's oldest independently owned eateries, on the corner of Eighth Street and 16th Avenue. Polar Bear closed last week. Zip's anticipates opening May 1. \n \n--- \n \nWilliams may be contacted at ewilliam@lmtribune.com or (208) 848-2261.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Best of biz / Elaine Williams"},"topics":[{"name":"Shipping industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"The Port of Lewiston - a new year, same story","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204316296","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:16Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/lmtribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/c8/ac8e66cd-1b85-5efc-a7a7-4457c4235694/588be35de229d.image.jpg?resize=300%2C98"}],"video":[]}}

Airlines' fourth-quarter profit fell but met Wall Street expectations, and a key measurement of revenue trends rose for the first time since late 2014, further evidence that airlines are finally starting to push average prices higher. \n \nAmerican executives echoed officials at other airlines in reporting that demand for travel has picked up since the November election. \n \nBut the airline also reported a 17 percent spike in labor spending after new union contracts, and it warned that costs will rise sharply again in the first quarter. \n \nShares of American Airlines Group Inc. fell $2.64, or 5.3 percent, to close at $46.95 on Friday. \n \nSeparately, American executives said that they would revive a previously rejected bid to work more closely with Australian carrier Qantas. The airlines want to work together on setting prices and schedules, which is forbidden without an exemption from antitrust laws. \n \nThe Obama administration rejected immunity for the deal, but airline-industry officials believe that the new Trump administration will be friendlier. \n \n\"We are hopeful that the Trump administration will give the Qantas joint venture a second and more favorable look,\" said Stephen Johnson, American's executive vice president. \n \nJohnson added that American, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines are also asking the administration to re-examine whether Middle Eastern carriers Emirates, Qatar Airways and Etihad Airways are violating an open-skies treaty by receiving unfair subsidies from their governments. The Obama administration did not act on the U.S. carriers' complaints. \n \nAt airports around the country, momentum is clearly swinging toward higher fares. \n \nAmerican predicted that total revenue for every seat flown one mile in the first quarter would be 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent higher than in early 2016. That is a more optimistic forecast than rivals have offered, although comparisons can be tricky - American includes some revenue, such as from credit-card deals, that other airlines don't include. \n \nThe same figure rose 1.3 percent in the fourth quarter, the first such increase in so-called unit revenue since the last quarter of 2014, American said. \n \nThat trend is not an accident. Airlines have been slowing their growth to tighten the supply of seats and drive up average fares. American said it would add only 1 percent to passenger-carrying capacity this year. \n \nAmerican is taking other steps to boost revenue. Next month it will start selling \"basic economy\" tickets designed to win over passengers from discount airlines like Spirit and Frontier. It also plans to offer \"premium economy\" tickets on international flights that would be better than a regular economy seat but less expensive than business class. \n \nAmerican's costs, however, are rising sharply. Because of profit sharing and higher wages in new union contracts, the company spent $2.8 billion on labor in the fourth quarter, an increase of more than $400 million in a year, which CFRA Research analyst Jim Corridore called alarming. And American predicted that costs per mile would jump 9 percent in the first quarter. \n \n\"It's great that they've got unit revenue moving in the right direction, but investors are very focused on costs,\" Corridore said. The iHeart80s Party rocked the SAP Center in San Jose, California with a star-studded lineup of artists including New Kids on the Block , UB40 Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey, Colin Hay of   Men At Work , Rick Astley , Starship ,  Eddie Money , and Night Ranger . And it was all hosted by iconic MTV personality Martha Quinn, who hosts the iHeart80s Radio's weekday morning show. \n \n{ \"position1\" : { \"type\" : \"live\", \"id\" : 5060, \"name\" : \"iHeart80s Radio\", \"description\" : \"Commercial-Free 80s Hits\" } } \n \nThe night was filled with some RAD moments from all of the performances of the night, amazing fan reactions, special guests, and more. Check out the best moments from the show below: \n Candace Cameron Bure -- AKA D.J. TANNER -- Helped Kick Off The Night By Introducing New Kids On The Block  \nIn case you didn\u2019t know, Candace is a huge NKOTB fan, and has been over the last 30 years. The band and Bure united on her show Fuller House , so there was no one better to introduce the band and kick off the show than D.J. Tanner herself. \n   New Kids On The Block Brought All The Right Stuff  \nNew Kids On The Block are one of the O.G. boybands, and after over 30 years of performing together, the guys still have  the right stuff . NKOTB took the stage to perform hits like \u201cStep By Step,\u201d \u201cYou Got It (The Right Stuff),\u201d and more, and brought all of their amazing dance moves with them. And yes, we\u2019re talking about those classic steps you learned from watching their music videos. \n Also, the NKOTB fans were out in FULL FORCE. Donnie couldn\u2019t resist\u2026  Starship Reminds Us \u201cWe are all citizens of the world.\u201d  \nAt the very end of their performance at the 2017 iHeart80s Party, which also happened to be the day as President Donald Trump\u2019s Immigration Ban which sparked protests across the country, Starship lead singer Mickey Thomas simply told the crowd, \u201cRemember, we are all citizens of the world.\u201d \n  \n. @starshipcontrol is giving us life right now! \"Remember we are all citizens of the WORLD!\" #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/y0MS7c5uPK \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Rick Astley Opened His Set With A Classic Rickroll  \nAstley kicked off his set with a classic Rickroll by leading fans to believe he was going to open with \u201cNever Gonna Give You Up\u201d by having his band play the instrumentals, but instead he kicked things off with his Whenever You Need Somebody single \u201cTogether Forever.\u201d Also during his set, the \u201880s icon, who turns 50 on February 6th, made jokes about his age and blamed it for his lack of dance numbers and inability to play high-energy songs back-to-back. \n UB40\u2019s \u201cRed Red Wine\u201d Had Everybody Feeling So Fine  \nUB40  Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey  took us all back to 1983 with their hit \u201cRed Red Wine.\u201d The crowd went wild during the band\u2019s performance of the beloved tune -- everybody was feeling it. \n  \nRed red wine has everybody feeling so fine #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/Zf5PhZcv0A \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Not to mention the band themselves\u2026   \nTime to sway.   @WeAreUB40 takes the stage now at our #iHeart80sParty in San Jose! INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"}],"wordCount":"594","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396193645&p=2kx&v=1&x=Hh7Kyunw7jFsX0VncleGWA","id":"29396193645","content":"Be ready to make choices if the standoff between Cable One and KAYU FOX has you considering cutting your cable service. \n \nKAYU FOX, the network carrying this year's Super Bowl, hasn't aired through Cable One in the Lewiston-Clarkston Valley since Jan. 1 because of a disagreement over retransmission fees. \n \nThe following Q&A provides some of the alternatives for receiving network channels, sports, movies and shows. \n \nQ: How can I get network affiliates such as FOX, CBS, ABC, NBC and PBS if I don't have cable? \n \nA: Cable One is distributing free antennas that allow you to capture those channels. They can also be purchased at places like Deranleau's, Walgreens, Shopko, Rite Aid and Walmart, sometimes appearing in the \"As Seen On TV\" displays. The cost ranges from $12 to $30, but finding one might be tough. Deranleau's has struggled to keep them in stock this month. The down side to antennas is that bad weather can interfere with reception, said Dan Jimenez, sales manager at Deranleau's in Lewiston. \n \nQ: What if I want to watch more than the major networks? \n \nA: First get high-speed internet. Cable One has options starting at about $50 a month for the service, but the price can vary depending on how much speed and data you want. Other providers that serve this market include Century Link, Rodeo Internet and First Step Internet. \n \nSubscribe to a service such as Sling TV, Hulu, Netflix or Amazon Prime. Look at the offerings first to find a good match for your tastes. Sling has a 30-plus channel package with ESPN, ESPN2, ESPN3, CNN, Newsy and Bloomberg Television for $20 per month. \n \nHulu, Netflix and Amazon Prime carry a variety of television shows and movies. Hulu starts at $8 per month for an option that has commercials. It offers current season shows from major U.S. networks the day after they run. Netflix is as little as $8 per month and doesn't have commercials. Amazon Prime runs $11 per month and includes other services such as free expedited shipping on Amazon orders. \n \nThese services include other features. They have multiple seasons of shows, so you can binge watch something you missed. You may or may not save money depending on which options you pick. One of Cable One's most popular cable packages costs $80 per month. \n \nYou could also skip the subscriptions entirely and instead budget for an amount each month to buy movies or shows on digital video discs. \n \nQ: What do I need to get content I purchase from one of those services to appear on my television? \n \nA: First, check the streaming media player in your television. About seven or eight years ago, most televisions began to be sold with the technology that connects the televisions to the internet, said Bill Steiner, an owner of Steiner Electronics in Lewiston. Gaming devices such as Sony PlayStation, Microsoft Xbox and Nintendo Wii have similar capabilities. \n \nIf what you already own doesn't have the applications for the content you have selected, look into a stand alone streaming media player, which can be connected to your television, Steiner said. Some examples are the Amazon Fire TV Stick ($40), Apple TV (about $150) or a Roku (about $100). \n \nQ: What about satellite television? \n \nA: Offerings such as DISH and DIRECTV can cost as little as $40 per month and provide content similar to cable. Keep in mind that weather conditions can occasionally interfere with reception and just like cable, satellite television customers sometimes are cut off from networks. Cable companies and satellite providers both negotiate deals to air major networks and other content. \n \n--- \n \nWilliams may be contacted at ewilliam@lmtribune.com or (208) 848-2261.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"ELAINE WILLIAMS of the Tribune"},"topics":[{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Ready to cut the cable?","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204323981","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:19Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/lmtribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/66/f6661374-aa61-5d7d-bdb4-245b8e13ba5e/588be35ea8347.image.jpg?resize=300%2C257"}],"video":[]}}

franchise agreement allowing Cable One to operate in Lewiston expires this December. \n \nThe agreement gives the city 5 percent of gross revenue, which has equaled about $220,000 in recent years, compared with the city's overall budget of about $64 million, said Lewiston Administrative Services Director Dan Marsh. \n \nIt also requires Cable One to provide programming in eight broad categories, but doesn't specify what the channels are. \n \nThe categories are news, weather, sports, entertainment, children's shows, education, cultural programming of local interest and governmental programming. \n \nThe number of channels is \"no less that the number of channels provided\" by Cable One at the start of the agreement. \n \nIt's not clear how happy Lewiston residents are with service from Cable One. City officials last week were unable to find the results of subscriber surveys that are required by the agreement once every five years. \n \nWhat Cable One offers has been evolving in recent years. The company dropped Viacom channels such as MTV in 2014. It is not carrying KAYU-FOX because of a disagreement over retransmission fees. \n \nCable One has stated previously it has no intention of leaving the cable business, but it has told stock market analysts it's putting its emphasis on pursuing high-speed internet customers. \n \nIt's too early to know if Lewiston's elected officials will view negotiating a new contract as an opportunity to influence how Cable One approaches the Lewiston market, said Lewiston Mayor Jim Kleeburg. \n \nWhatever direction Lewiston goes would likely involve cooperation with the city of Clarkston and Asotin County. \n \nThose municipalities have similar agreements with Cable One, but they end at different times. Clarkston's runs through 2019, and Asotin County's ends in either 2023 or 2024 (the current contract lists both years). \n \nWere a company other than Cable One to seek to serve the Lewiston-Clarkston Valley, it would likely have to acquire the cable provider's infrastructure, said Joe Poire, executive director of the Port of Whitman County, who spent 11 years in the cable industry. \n \nThe public telecommunications network being constructed by the ports of Lewiston and Clarkston wouldn't have the capacity to serve a new company without significant investment that goes beyond what's contemplated, Poire said. \n \nNo law requires communities to be served by cable companies, according to the Federal Communications Commission, which regulates the industry. \n \nBut the chances of the Lewiston-Clarkston Valley ending up without cable services are low, regardless of what happens in the telecommunications industry, Poire said. \n \n\"The ... market is big enough it's a viable asset.\" \n \n--- \n \nWilliams may be contacted at ewilliam@lmtribune.com or (208) 848-2261.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"ELAINE WILLIAMS of the Tribune"},"topics":[{"name":"Cable Greenwood. \n\nUpon graduating from high school in Kerrville, Jo received her college degree at Trinity in San Antonio, Texas and began her working career in the Texas Valley as the Educational Director in the Presbyterian Church. After her stint in the valley, Jo went to Austin where she worked in the Educational Department of Presbyterian Synod of Texas, then preceded to New York where she worked in the Union Theological Seminary, and from there she resided in Teaneck, New Jersey where Jo completed her degree in Montessori Education from Sairleigh-Dickinson College. With her education now completed Jo married the love of her life, Dr. John Redden, the Veterinarian at the time in Kerrville Texas! Dr. John was also a landscape artist working in oils and also painted the Native American pictographs on rocks, all of which he kept in his own private collection. For 12 years Jo taught Montessori Education in Kerrville to pre schoolers, that is from 2 ½ years old until they started first grade. I started running just after Christmas and just working through that at the moment. It's a lot of hard work at the moment but looking good,\" Suckling said from the Sunshine Coast. \n \n\"I suppose when you do get injured you always worry that it's going to happen again but that's why probably over the break you put in so much effort and so much work so you can come back and it won't let you down again.\" \n \n\"It's certainly a lot harder (with the heat) and sessions have been really hard but the boys love getting up here because a few boys like getting a tan so they're very happy with that,\" Suckling said. \n  \nThe Western Bulldogs left last Wednesday for the annual pre-season camp and returned late on Sunday night. \n \nAnd Suckling, who originally was recruited from the Wagga Tigers by Hawthorn, scoffed at suggestions that his missed flag opportunity was being used as a pre-season source of motivation. \n \n\"Not really. She hadn't played for about three months before coming here, and it easier to do these things. \n \n\"But she's playing very well, and records are made to be broken. \n  \n\"People keep asking me, 'How do you feel about your record?' but I'm not going to lose any sleep over something like that. \n \n\"My life is very busy and full, and they'll never get my 64 so it's all right. how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"452","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396194101&p=2kx&v=1&x=vWNAr3RVAGW-ZAmMFsRQYg","id":"29396194101","content":"London, Jan 29 (PTI) Scientists have discovered a key \u2018survival gene\u2019 that prevents strains of tuberculosis (TB) from mutating into drug-resistant \u2018superbugs\u2019. \n \nResearchers from the Centro Nacional de Biotecnologia in Spain and the University of Sussex in the UK identified the gene called NucS that dramatically reduces mutation rates in mycobacteria \u2013 the infectious microbe which causes TB. \n \nTB, which is spread through the air, is one of the top 10 causes of death worldwide, researchers said. \n \nDrug-resistant strains of TB have already been identified in 105 countries and researchers believe that a key gene, required to suppress mutation rates in mycobacteria, may help understand how \u2018superbugs\u2019 develop. \n \nUsing a genetic screen, which involved individually knocking out nearly every gene (11,000 genes) in mycobacteria, and screening whether mutant strains grew on a specific antibiotic (rifampicin), scientists discovered that a DNA repair enzyme, produced by the NucS gene, dramatically reduces mutations from occurring. \n \nThe researchers also discovered that genetic variations in the NucS gene significantly influence the mutation rates in clinically isolated strains of mycobacteria. \n \nThe scientists believe the discovery could also play a role in understanding the development of antibiotic-resistance in patients already suffering from TB. \n \n\u201cThe rise of antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health and, if we are to limit its impact on infectious diseases, we first need to identify the mechanisms that prevent bacteria from mutating in the first place,\u201d said Aidan Doherty, a professor at the University of Sussex. \n \n\u201cThis knowledge will then enable us to better understand how pathogens develop into \u2018superbugs\u2019,\u201d Doherty said. \n \n\u201cIncredibly, for many years it was believed that mycobacteria lacked any mutation avoidance genes,\u201d he said. \n \nThe discovery that the NucS gene reduces the rate at which mutations occur in these pathogens is a crucial first step towards identifying the genetic factors that influence the onset of antibiotic-resistance,\u201d said Doherty. \n \n\u201cThis will enable scientists and clinicians to screen for strains that are most likely to develop drug-resistance and figure out strategies to tackle this serious threat,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cNot only does this study identify that mutations can be reversed in mycobacteria, it reveals that the loss of this DNA repair process can cause a huge increase in the mutation rates, significantly increasing the likelihood of these pathogens acquiring mutations \u2013 which can cause antibiotic resistance,\u201d Professor Jesus Blazquez, from the Centro Nacional de Biotecnologia, said. \n \n\u201cNow we know that that NucS dramatically reduces mutation rates in mycobacteria \u2013 it is vital that we take advantage of this and work towards exploiting this discovery to help doctors and microbiologists to predict and prevent the development of antibiotic resistance during treatments,\u201d said Blazquez. \n \nThe study was published in the journal Nature Communications. \n \nThis is published unedited from the PTI feed.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Press Trust of India"},"topics":[{"name":"Public health ARIZONA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MEXICO","domains":["GEO"],"score":"99"},{"name":"NORTH AMERICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JOHN MCCAIN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JEFF FLAKE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"750","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396193952&p=2kx&v=1&x=IkAvzqonwBL6H8L4wRiPsQ","id":"29396193952","content":"MEXICO CITY - If President Donald Trump makes good on threats to gut NAFTA and impose stiff tariffs on Mexican goods, economists say he risks a trade war that could lead to the very thing he is hoping to avoid - a huge surge in Mexican migration to the United States. \n \nThe result would be catastrophe for the Mexican economy: Recession. A dramatic weakening of the peso, even below the historic lows it has already set amid Trump's bellicose rhetoric. Soaring inflation, interest rates and unemployment. \n \n\"Mexico is smaller than the U.S. and can be harmed by conflict more than the U.S. would be,\" said Adam Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, a Washington think tank that supports free trade. \n \nA trade war with Mexico \"drives down the peso and drives down opportunities for Mexicans to make a living in honest manufacturing jobs,\" he added. \"There will be more desperate Mexicans crossing the border.\" \n \nAnd the U.S. would by no means be immune from the fallout. \n \nMexico is the United States' third-largest trading partner, with about $583.6 billion in cross-border commerce in 2015, according to the Office of the United States Trade Representative. That included a U.S. trade deficit of $58 billion. America buys about 80 percent of Mexico's exports, with automobiles, electrical machinery and fuels topping a long list that also includes agricultural goods such as fruit, vegetables, wine and beer. \n \nThe Trump administration's proposal this week for a 20 percent tax on imports from Mexico to pay for the promised border wall was quickly walked back by officials as just one of multiple \"options.\" \n \nIt could also face stiff opposition in Congress, including from Republicans who favor free trade. Those include Sens. John McCain and Jeff Flake of the border state of Arizona, who publicly came out in support of NAFTA. McCain noted that it has increased his state's exports to Mexico and Canada by $5.7 billion, or 236 percent, since its enactment in 1994. \n \nThe worst case scenario of a trade war is frightening to contemplate, economists said. \n \nIf the U.S. were to slap a tax on Mexican imports, it would violate the terms of NAFTA and nullify the pact, said Alfredo Coutino, Latin America director at Moody's Analytics. \n \nMexico could impose retaliatory tariffs, and the resulting uncertainty would spook investors and businesses, including U.S. companies with operations in Mexico that could pull out. \n \nThe peso, already sorely weakened at about 21 to the dollar, could fall to 25, 28 or even lower, Coutino continued. Unemployment would rise. Mexicans' real purchasing power would plummet as a result, and inflation could soar to double digits by the end of the year. Interest rates could also top 10 percent. The Mexican government would be forced into fiscal tightening measures, putting additional downward pressure on the economy and throwing it into recession. \n \nAmerica would suffer too, but not as much. Moody's forecasts that a trade war would slightly reduce U.S. economic growth and cost 300,000 American jobs after a year. \n \nMexico has been here before, most notably when a sharp peso devaluation in 1994 touched off a nearly 6 percent economic contraction. \n \nHundreds of thousands of Mexican job-seekers poured over the border into the United States, one of the reasons the U.S. organized a $50 billion International Monetary Fund bailout of its southern neighbor in 1995. \n \nIf the U.S. economy keeps improving while Mexico's tanks, experts said, expect more of the same. And bulking up the physical barrier may not keep migrants out, with some estimates saying 40 percent of illegal immigration results from people who come to the U.S. legally and then overstay their visas. Canada does not require visas of Mexican citizens, so there's nothing to stop people from flying to Canada and crossing the United States' porous northern frontier. \n \nCritics said the U.S. president's obsession with illegal migration ignores the fact that the phenomenon has waned dramatically in recent years, and point to the irony that his policies could reverse that trend. The Pew Research Center reported in November that the number of unauthorized Mexican immigrants in the U.S. fell from 6.95 million in 2007, to 5.85 to million in 2014. \n \nCoutino predicted that economic chaos in Mexico would strengthen the cartels that traffic drugs into the U.S. - another stated target of the border wall - as unemployed people are more vulnerable to recruitment by the gangs. \n \n\"You will have a neighbor to the south of your border with unemployment, with social problems, with rising criminality,\" Coutino said. \"Do you want to have a neighbor like that? That's the question that Trump and his team should be asking themselves.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"PETER ORSI and PAUL WISEMAN Of The"},"topics":[{"name":"Central America news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Mexico news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Analysts: Trump's harsh words about Mexico could backfire","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204332523","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:23Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The former Barcelona academy prodigy later issued an apology for his conduct via his social media outlets. \n \nHaving coped relatively comfortably with Lazio's territorial domination, the visitors held out through a frantic five minutes of added-on time to claim a win that bolsters the buffer between them and the relegation battle. \n \nFor Lazio it was a second successive defeat after Simone Inzaghi's squad's tame surrender at leaders Juventus last weekend. \n \nAnd the suddenly under-pressure coach admitted he had his work cut out to turn things around. \n \n\"It is a defeat that will take its toll on morale, but as the head of this group I have to be big enough to get it off the players' backs and get them going again. \n \n\"The only thing to say is that we have to be more efficient in front of goal. previous speeches given by both Trump\u2019s republican and democratic predecessors \n \nThe White House issued a statement defending US president Donald Trump\u2019s Holocaust remembrance day speech on Friday that had no mention of Jews or anti-Semitism because it was meant to include \u201dall of those who suffered.\u201d \n \nA spokeswoman for the Trump administration, Hope Hicks, told CNN on Saturday that, \"despite what the media reports, we are an incredibly inclusive group and we took into account all of those who suffered,\" \n \nHicks retorted that the speech was meant to be inclusive of all those who suffered during the Holocaust including the five million non-Jews who were murdered in the genocide orchestrated by Adolf Hitler. \n \n\u201cPriests, gypsies, people with mental or physical disabilities, communists, trade unionists, Jehovah's Witnesses, anarchists, Poles and other Slavic peoples, and resistance fighters,\u201d she noted. \n \nThe speech came under fire by several Jewish organization leaders, who found it \u201cpuzzling and troubling\u201d that it failed to explicitly mention the six million Jews who perished in a targeted genocide against them. \n \n\n \n\u201cIt is with a heavy heart and somber mind that we remember and honor the victims, survivors, and heroes of the Holocaust,\u201d the presidential statement read. \u201cIt is impossible to fully fathom the depravity and horror inflicted on innocent people by Nazi terror.\u201d \n \nTrump has been accused of flirting with alleged white supremacist and neo-Nazi during his controversial presidential campaign. \n \nAnti-Defamation League (ADL) Director Jonathan Greenblatt expressed his disapproval of the speech in a series of tweets. which he felt downplayed the suffering and persecution of the Jewish people in the Holocaust, a common theme of nationalist movements, he added according to CNN . \n \nHe also noted that the speech was a departure from previous speeches given by both Trump\u2019s republican and democratic predecessors. \n  \n2/2 Puzzling and troubling @WhiteHouse  #HolocaustMemorialDay stmt has no mention of Jews. Goldstein, echoed Greenblatt\u2019s criticism of Trump\u2019s oblique phrasing. \n \n\u201cHow can you forget, Mr President, that six million Jews were murdered because they were Jews?\u201d Goldstein remarked. \n \n\u201cYou chose the vague phrase \u2018innocent people.\u2019 They were Jews, Mr President.\u201d \n \nIn a statement to CNN, Greenblatt mentioned that International Holocaust Remembrance Day was put in place because of Holocaust denials, but also the numerous countries such as Iran, Russia, Poland, and Hungary, who refuse to recognize Hitler\u2019s attempt to exterminate Jews, \"opting instead to talk about generic suffering rather than recognizing this catastrophic incident for what is was: the intended genocide of the Jewish people.\" \n \n\n \nCNN also reported that after being asked about ADL\u2019s criticism and the omission Jews or anti-Semitism, Ronald Lauder of the World Jewish Congress responded with a critique of Greenblatt\u2019s accusation. \n statement today on the International Holocaust Memorial Day will see it appropriately commemorates the suffering and the heroism that mark that dark chapter in modern history,\" the statement Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HOUSTON, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; VICTORIA, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"450","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396194599&p=2kx&v=1&x=XvzMLSYNvuphzXR2FI7GGA","id":"29396194599","content":"Donald Trump's Muslim ban banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families, says Melbourne's Somalian community. \n\nIt's a place that sings of the Australian summer: lemon-scented gums, the trill of cicadas, sand underfoot and a sliver of navy ocean on the horizon.\n\nHussein Haraco and 35 other men from Melbourne's Somalian community had driven down for a weekend at an Anglesea holiday camp.\n\nThey were there to talk leadership; how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. (Video: Qantas) \n   Wolves shock Liverpool in FA Cup  \nPlay Video  Don't Play \n  Video duration  01:31         Video duration  01:31   Wolves shock Liverpool in FA Cup   Wolves shock Liverpool in FA Cup  \nThe first shock of the FA Cup 4th round came at Anfield where a 2-1 victory for Wolves ended Liverpool's final realistic chance of silverware this season. \n      Warner prepares for India's challenges  \nDavid Warner sets his sights on adapting to the challenges of playing in India. \n   \nFormer captain Steve Waugh famously told his players in 2001 to immerse themselves in all that India has to offer, insisting that it would be a \"no-whinge tour\", a theme continued under Gilchrist in 2004 when he deputised for an injured Ricky Ponting. The approach was in contrast to the attitude taken by a key member of the 2013 tour who was privately dreading spending the next seven weeks on the road. \n \nGilchrist spoke to several of Australia's Test squad and backroom staff, including coach Darren Lehmann and batting coach Graeme Hick, when the side was in Perth recently for the one-day international against Pakistan . He told them \"attitude is all important\" for the seven-week tour. \n Rare occurrence: The Australians celebrate their series win in India in 2004.  Photo:   \n\"I was very much a follower and believer of most things Steve Waugh was talking to us about. I took that very much on board and tried to do that as much as possible, still do now. I find it a fascinating country,\" Gilchrist, who has business interests in India, told Fairfax Media. \n \n\"It's a country that weighs you down, too. You have highs and lows, it's an emotional roller-coaster, on the field and off the field. \n  \n\"You've got to find a way to escape from it \u2013 if it's in your hotel room, but you don't want to become a prisoner to your hotel room, you have to get out there. \n \n\"It's [attitude] going to be a huge percentage of what's required. The ingredients to success is a positive attitude, not just positive like you have to use your feet and go after the spinner but everything.\" \n \nGilchrist said Waugh, in a bid to keep morale high, told the players at the start of the tour \"attitudes are contagious, is yours worth catching?\" \n \n\"From that, he extended it, saying this will be a 'no whinge tour',\" Gilchrist said. \"Forever we've come to India and we're beaten before we get here. We're whinging about the food, the conditions, the umpiring and the hotel room, the flights. We weren't allow to whinge, pretty much. It was amazing. \n \n\"It's a great question you can ask yourself every day: how you think is how you feel and that's how you're going to act, is yours worth catching? And that really helped. We didn't get the chocolates on that tour but it was a strong foundation to what lay ahead.\" \n \nAustralia's players were also given a mid-tour break between Tests in 2004, which allowed them to spend time in Singapore and the Maldives with family and partners. The current squad has been given time off between the second and third Tests but they will not be leaving the country. \n \nOn the field, Gilchrist said, Australia needed to buck with tradition and adopt a more conservative game plan like the 2004 team did. Smith has already foreshadowed a more defensive strategy with the bat. \n \n\"That allowed us to get into the game without being blown away and the deeper you take it the more chance you are,\" Gilchrist said. \"The tactics will be important.\" \n \nWhile Ponting has said a competitive series loss would be a positive, Gilchrist is drawing hope from England's strong start to their recent series against India where they fell just short of victory in the first Test. But he said it would be \"frightfully difficult\". \n \n\"There's no reason why they can't get there and start well and build up confidence and be competitive about challenging for the series,\" Gilchrist said. \n \n\"As is the way in India momentum swings, whether it's an innings, a Test or a series, once it's against you it's a hard freight train to stop.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Andrew Wu"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: EPL - Liverpool news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"India news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Indian subcontinent news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"India v Australia Test series: Adam Gilchrist tells Australia to embrace India","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"4000","state":"Queensland","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Brisbane Adelaide Street","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Brisbane Times","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169658354","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"191"},"name":"Brisbane Times","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Cricket","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204346072","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:24:19Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:31Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
