Hunt Dumont to set aside the verdict and have a new trial ordered.\n\nAfter a two-month civil trial, Bailey was awarded $50,000 in damages and an additional $37,403 on Tuesday, Dec. 20, to cover lost wages when she took a nine-month leave of absence in 2014 after being diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder, after a Morris County civil jury found that she had suffered emotional distress and was a victim of harassment because of her gender by higher ranking officers in the department.\n\nBailey received a separate check for $40,000 from the township to cover lost wages in 2014.\n\nHarrison claimed in his motion that the jury was incorrectly told by the judge that Bailey had participated in three counts of \"protected activity\" under . Two of the instances were separate conversations in 2010 and 2011 between Bailey former Randolph Police Chief Robert Mason in which she said it was unfair that female officers be penalized for using sick days to take care of sick children at home according to court documents.\n\nThe conversations took place after Bailey was passed over for a promotion to sergeant in consecutive years.\n\nThe third instance was Bailey's continued efforts to seek that promotion while she maintained a good faith despite her belief that gender discrimination existed within the department.\n\nAttorneys Richard Murray and Omar Lopez, who represented Bailey in the trial, have opposed Harrison's motion.\n\nAccording to court papers, Murray said that Harrison \"failed to demonstrate clearly and convincingly that there has been a miscarriage of justice that warrants a new trial.\"\n\nIn the court papers, Murray argues that Dumont's legal charge to the jury and on the verdict sheet were correct, despite Harrison's claims.\n\nHarrison wrote that the three acts and evidence in the trail did not establish protected activity under Law Against Discrimination and that the only protected activity was the filing of the 2012 lawsuit.\n\nHarrison claimed that Bailey's supervisors did not treat her any differently than they would treat any of the male police officers in the department and called witnesses at the trail to support his claim.\n\nThe verdict sheet did not specify which actions of the ranking officers originally named as defendants by Bailey were found to be offensive or discriminatory towards Bailey and resulted in the award.\n\nBy the end of the trial, Randolph Township was the sole defendant in the case although when she originally filed the lawsuit in 2012, Bailey had sued Mason, current Randolph Police Chief David Stokoe, Lts. William Harzula and Christopher Giuliani and former Township Manager John Lovell.\n\nIn the trail, Bailey alleged that she had been passed over for the promotion to sergeant because of her gender and that after questioning Mason about the results of her sergeants exams, which she did not pass, she was intimidated by Mason.\n\nShe testified that Mason pressed his body up against hers and that she was the target of internal affairs investigations and corrective action mandates, which she alleged were not endured my male officers on the force.\n\nDuring the trial, the jury found that Bailey did not prove that she should have been promoted to sergeant.\n\nA date has not yet been set for the judge to hear Harrison's motion for a new trial.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Police news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Randolph Police Department files motion for new trial in discrimination case","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Rock Island","zipCode":"61265","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Moline","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"The Progress","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169670235","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"The Progress","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://newjerseyhills.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.randolphnj.org/","http://www.randolphnj.org/POLICE","http://www.nj.gov/oag/dcr/law.html#LAD"],"sequenceId":"695204346428","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:32Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; IDAHO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"MIKE CRAPO","domains":["PEO"],"score":"55"},{"name":"JIM RISCH","domains":["PEO"],"score":"50"},{"name":"RON WYDEN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"326","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396194939&p=2kx&v=1&x=wXm4fbAaKuixQQvJx8miIw","id":"29396194939","content":"SALEM, Ore. - A U.S. Forest Service program that infused rural communities with millions to make up for lost timber revenue is drying up, and that means Oregon will see a 90 percent reduction in the payments that have kept critical services afloat in many counties since environmental rules curtailed logging nearly 30 years ago. \n \nThe Salem Statesman Journal reported Friday that the changes will impact more than 700 counties and 4,000 school districts in 41 states. \n \nThe Secure Rural Schools program was enacted in 2000 to help ease the financial blow after a dramatic reduction in logging in the 1990s. \n \nBut the program has not been reauthorized and payments going forward will revert to a 1908 law that dedicates 25 percent of timber revenues to local governments. \n \nFor Oregon, the reduction would be particularly severe, dropping the 2015 payment of $86.4 million to $7 million, according to an analysis by the National Association of Counties. Polk County would see payments almost completely dry up after a reduction from $782,406 to $318. \n \nFor Marion County, the reduction would be from $1.8 million to $186,880, an 89.8 percent reduction. About 25 percent of Marion County, and 26.4 percent of the state of Oregon, is Forest Service land. \n \nThe law had provided gradually reduced payments since 2012 and was authorized a final time at $285 million in April 2015 and expired six months later. \n \nPayments to counties at the previous 25 percent level will start to be sent out in February, said Babete R. Anderson, the national press officer for the Forest Service. \n \n\"We are working through the steps required to process the 25 percent fund payments expeditiously and anticipate making those payments by the middle of February,\" she said. \n \nThe National Association of Counties is trying to drum up support for reauthorizing the program - and some Western lawmakers are listening. \n \nSen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., was a co-author of the 2000 bill and is working with Sen. Mike Crapo and Sen. from across the country recently tackled a project that had nothing to do with surgery or a medical diagnosis, as they helped clean up McDowell Creek County Park between Lebanon and Sweet Home. \n \nStudents from 38 osteopathic medical colleges across the United States were attending the Council of Osteopathic Government Presidents conference at COMP-Northwest in Lebanon. \n \nThe annual conference always includes a student service project, the Albany Democrat-Herald reported. \n \nAccording to county parks Director Brian Carroll, the adage \"many hands make light work\" was certainly true as the medical crew in one hour completed work that would have taken staff at least a day. \n \nThe volunteers removed debris from trails that had been damaged in recent winter storms, helped repair a staircase at the top of the falls and spread five yards of gravel at a picnic table area. \n \n\"I know, for them, it doesn't seem like much, but for us it really helps out,\" he said. \n \nCarroll said he appreciated the work of the medical students, and the project also gave them a chance to see the scenic falls area while they were in Oregon. \n \nCarroll added that so far, the parks have not experienced as much damage as in some other winters. \n \n\"We lost a really large cottonwood at Waterloo County Park,\" Carroll said. \"Knock on wood, we've actually fared better than in some recent winters, when ice storms and high winds have done much more damage.\" \n \nCarroll speculated that perhaps those storms thinned out weaker trees. \n \n\"Last winter we had major damage to our boat ramps from flooding, especially on the North Santiam,\" Carroll said. \"So far, we haven't had any reports of anything really severe.\" \n \n\"We do remind visitors to our parks that they should look up now and then, just in case there might be a widow-maker hanging in a tree,\" Carroll said. \n \nCarroll said that water is turned off in the county parks that aren't open in the winter, so he probably won't know about any broken pipes until water is turned back on in the spring. \n \n\"We've had a lot of snow at Clear Lake, so we've been shoveling it off the roofs,\" Carroll said. \"It's probably the most snow we've had since the really bad winter of 2006-07.\" \n \nClear Lake remains open for boat and cabin rentals, Carroll said, although the lodge and restaurant are closed. \n \n\"We encourage anyone headed to Clear Lake to take chains, no matter what the other road conditions are,\" Carroll said. \"We're not on the main road and we get a lot of snow, even when other places don't. We plow and sand, but sometimes, even with studded tires, you need chains.\" \n \nThe conference for the Council of Osteopathic Student Government Presidents touched on a variety of topics, including mental health awareness, women in leadership, and political advocacy. \n \nThe service project is a requirement for a school to host the annual conference. \n \nDylan Rodgers, president of the COMP-Northwest Class of 2019, applied in September to have Western U act as COMP-Northwest host. \n \nThe Lebanon campus welcomed 72 student government presidents and vice presidents, as well as an additional 12 students who had previously served as student government leaders. \n \n\"I knew that the family-centered culture of the students, staff, and faculty of COMP-Northwest would provide for {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29391833561","companies":[{"symbol":"GCCO","primary":true,"name":"Garden City Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3648561047"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BIRDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"BIRDING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"THERMAL SENSORS","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"BOISE, ID, USA; UNITED STATES; IDAHO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; IDAHO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"420","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396194925&p=2kx&v=1&x=C4OAj5PtJZD-W2QmvEy58w","id":"29396194925","content":"BOISE - Bird lovers in Idaho are worried that an unusually cold and snowy winter may have harmed or killed some of the Anna's hummingbirds that spend the winter there despite the chilly climate. \n \nSome bird lovers who feed the hummingbirds say they haven't spotted one since mid-December, and the last reported sighting of the tiny ruby-throated birds was Jan. 2, The Idaho Statesman reported Saturday. \n \nTemperatures as low as minus 11 have been recorded at the Boise airport. \n \n\"We don't have evidence they died off but I do suspect some of them did die,\" said Heidi Ware, education and outreach director at the Intermountain Bird Observatory, an academic research and outreach program of Boise State University. \n \nLast winter, Idaho bird-watchers spotted 55 Anna's hummingbirds, with most observed in Southwest Idaho and the Panhandle. This winter, 37 of the birds were noted. \n \nAbout two-thirds of the birds disappeared around mid-December last year as well, so it's unknown if there are fewer only because of the unusual weather. Last February, some of the birds that left returned - then departed again in March. \n \nThere have been five days below zero in January, with the lowest recorded temperature at the Boise Airport dropping to minus 11. \n \nOne bird-watcher who lives in the Garden City area saw an Anna's hummingbird in his yard in December, when the thermometer at his house read minus 8. \n \n\"With any bird, the reason they leave for the winter is not usually dependent on what temperatures they can survive. It's all about food,\" Ware said. \"It's about the food being there.\" \n \nIn general, birds try to consume enough food during the day to have enough fat to shiver through the night, Ware said. Hummingbirds go into \"torpor,\" a state of hibernation that allows them to burn less energy than other birds that don't. \n \n\"There's a lot of evidence that other larger birds aren't doing so well either in this unusual weather,\" Ware said. \"We've seen a number of reports of freezing finches at feeders, barn owls struggling to survive cold temps, and very cold northern flickers and western screech owls roosting under eaves to seek warmth.\" \n \nThe birds were first documented in Southern California in the early 1900s. Their range expanded to northern California by the 1950s, and then as far as Oregon and Washington by the 1960s and 1970s. \n \nThe first Anna's sightings in Idaho were in the mid-1970s and researchers now band the hummingbirds in Idaho to study their breeding and migration patterns. \n \n\"They're adapting and getting whatever resources they can get,\" Ware said.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Birders in Idaho worry harsh winter may cut populations of Anna's hummingbirds","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204350801","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:34Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SPOKANE, WA, USA; UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"630","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396194982&p=2kx&v=1&x=A4SpE3XmlGad5r_cebyyrQ","id":"29396194982","content":"SEATTLE - Some lawmakers are taking aim at a recent Washington Supreme Court decision that put the onus on counties to determine whether water is legally available in certain rural areas before they issue building permits. \n \nOne bill sponsored by Sen. Judy Warnick, R-Moses Lake, amends parts of the state law at the heart of the ruling, known as the Hirst decision. County officials, builders, business and farm groups are among supporting the measure, while environmental groups and tribes oppose it. \n \nA competing bill sponsored by Sen. John McCoy, D-Tulalip, supports the court decision and sets up a program to help counties find ways to meet the requirements. \n \nIn October, the high court ruled that Whatcom County failed to protect water resources by allowing new wells to reduce flow in streams for fish and other uses. The court said counties must ensure, independently of the state, that water is physically and legally available before they issue building permits in certain areas. \n \nIn the wake of the ruling, some counties have temporarily halted certain rural development, while others changed criteria for obtaining a building permit. \n \nAt issue is a struggle to balance competing needs of people and wildlife for limited water, a challenge that has played out across the state for years. \n \n\"We face a situation where people in rural areas who don't have the luxury of hooking up to city water now have very few options,\" Warnick said in a statement, noting many people rely on wells that previously were not an issue. \n \nShe said her measure, Senate Bill 5239, supports development in rural areas. It would allow counties to rely on state water rules, as they did before the Hirst decision, and ensure that so-called permit-exempt wells can be used for development. \n \nWater is a \"finite resource, and therefore we all need to work together to protect that resource,\" McCoy said. \"I don't feel that anyone wants to injure anyone's water right or seniority in this process, but we need to get to common ground.\" \n \nHis proposal, Senate Bill 5024, allows counties to set up a program to offset water that otherwise would be withdrawn from a well. The county could, for example, create a \"water bank\" where people who need water obtain it from those who have water rights. \n \nThe bill would give counties five years to come up with alternative ways to get water; meanwhile, people in the program could get a certificate allowing them to build. \n \nCommissioners from Spokane, Mason and Thurston counties told lawmakers their counties have relied on the state Department of Ecology to make water decisions, and they don't have the resources to do the kinds of hydrological studies that would be required. \n \n\"We need a legislative fix, and 5239 is that fix,\" said Mason County Commissioner Terri Jeffreys. \n \nBruce Wishart with the Sierra Club said SB5024 would allow for development to move forward while making sure it is done in a way that protects water kept in rivers for fish as well as for neighboring wells. \n \nDave Christensen of the Ecology Department told lawmakers the agency supported some elements of both bills but couldn't support either as written. \n \nZach Nutting, a Whatcom County resident, begged lawmakers to fix the problem, saying he put thousands of dollars toward building a home on a 5-acre property but hasn't been able to get a building permit because \"the well they told me I could drill, I can no longer drill.\" \n \nTim Ballew, chairman of the Lummi Nation, acknowledged the ruling's impact on people wanting to build a home. But he said recent Supreme Court decisions \"have all protected senior water rights holders that have been based on state laws dating back to 1917.\" \n \n\"I urge legislators to take a deep breath before considering rewriting 100 years of water policy,\" Ballew said.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"PHUONG LE Of the"},"topics":[],"title":"Legislators see competing water bills","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204351633","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:35Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/lmtribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/45/9453de70-a6eb-5735-b099-051e9c9c32bc/588d82392fd96.image.jpg?resize=300%2C191"}],"video":[]}}

Air Canada, WestJet and Porter Airlines are no longer letting people carrying passports from the seven countries board flights to the U.S. All three are waiving their cancellation fees.\" \n \nAs of Saturday at 5 pm EST Justin Trudeau had not commented on the order other than an indirect tweet stating, \"To those fleeing persecution, terror & war, Canadians will welcome you, regardless of your faith. Diversity is our strength.\" \n \nJahanzeb Hussain and Derrick O'Keefe comment in Ricochet, \"The Canadian government must immediately step up in both words and deeds to categorically reject Donald Trump\u2019s executive orders on immigration and refugee policy. ...To protect those directly affected and threatened by Trump\u2019s Muslim ban, the Canadian government should immediately grant temporary visas to anyone otherwise accepted for entry who is denied under Trump's racist and unconstitutional measures.\" \n \nNDP MP Jenny Kwan says, \"As global citizens and defenders of human rights, Canada must be willing to do its part in addressing the increase in the number of refugees that will be denied entry into the United States. On behalf of my New Democrat colleagues, I call on the new minister to present Canadians with a plan to address these serious concerns.\" \n \nTrudeau is scheduled to meet with Trump in the White House in late-February. \n \n#MuslimBan #MuslimBanProtest #JFKTerminal4 #NoBanNoWall \n ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Religion news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Trudeau should reject Trump's travel ban against seven Muslim-majority countries","source":{"category":"Organisation","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"CA","country":"Canada"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Council of Canadians","feed":{"genre":"Blog","tags":[],"id":"169742312","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"79"},"name":"Council of Canadians","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Organisations"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.canadians.org"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204352724","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:36Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29386344670","companies":[{"symbol":"BRKO","primary":true,"name":"Broke Out Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US1120931092"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RELIEF ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"DRIVERS LICENSES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"CONTINUING EDUCATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ERITREA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MONTANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ETHIOPIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"69"},{"name":"AFRICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"69"},{"name":"EASTERN AFRICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"69"},{"name":"MISSOULA, MT, USA; UNITED STATES; MONTANA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"1316","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195046&p=2kx&v=1&x=TpLh0Y-jzyxv4fM3hgHf2w","id":"29396195046","content":"MISSOULA, Mont. - It was a big week for Biniam Adhanom and his family. \n \nOn Jan. 10, the kids - Samrawit Gebrehawariat, age 9, and her brother, Ermias, 7 - started school in America. They climbed on the yellow bus that stops just outside their apartment on the Northside and rode out to Mount Jumbo School in East Missoula, the home of Lowell School this year. \n \nOn Jan. 11, Helen Reda, Adhanom's wife, started English classes at the Lifelong Learning Center. \n \nAnd on Jan. 12, Biniam took the written part of his driver's test at the Department of Motor Vehicles office. He passed with flying colors. \n \nUp next: the road test, a driver's license and a job - maybe not in that order. \n \n\"I'm ready,\" Adhanom said with a beaming smile. \"I cannot determine what, but I'm ready to work. And when I find myself working, I'm sure I will grow.\" \n \nAll this was happening with a backdrop of the strange stuff we call \"snow\" that keeps stacking up outside. There's no word for it in Tigrinya, the primary language of their native Eritrea. \n \n\"We are dressing like what the winter season demands,\" Adhanom said. \"We have been given full orientation, how we have to dress during the winter season, and we are up to that.\" \n \nOne of the first things Samrawit and Ermias learned at school, he said, was what \"snowball fight\" means. They're eager to try it out when the snow gets right. \n \nJan. 15 marked one month to the day since Biniam, Helen and the kids touched down in Missoula, refugees who spent the past eight years in Ethiopia, Eritrea's next-door enemy. \n \nThey were the last four of a dozen nationals from the obscure, oppressed country on the Horn of Africa to arrive under the auspices of the International Rescue Committee, the Missoulian reported. \n \nFew if any of the other 49 Congolese, Eritrean, Ethiopian, Iraqi and Syrian refugees who've landed in Missoula since August are better equipped for the new life than Adhanom. \n \nHe chatted affably in mostly understandable English, sitting on a couch in a sparse but comfortable living room. It was an early-out day from school for the kids. Helen, who understands English but isn't sure about speaking it yet, played with the children in a back room while her husband and IRC case worker Jen Barile visited with a reporter. \n \nPolite and what their father called \"very disciplined,\" Samrawit and Ermias showed off their recorder skills to their mother between frequent outbursts of giggles. \n \nThe 36-year-old Adhanom said his command of English is what he's most frequently asked about. \n \nThe explanation: He's earned degrees at two colleges: in education administration at the University of Asmara, in the capital of Eritrea; and in community development, with a minor in social work, at the Ethiopian Adventist College in Shashemene, 150 miles south of the capital of Addis Ababa. For the last 21/2 years he taught at the latter college. \n \nErmias was not yet born when the family fled Eritrea, where Adhanom said a dictatorial government mandates military service of an indeterminate length and personal freedom is a foreign concept. \n \n\"You cannot express your feelings. If you dissent, you'll be caught, you'll be jailed,\" he said. \"Life is so hard there. Lots of things that are very, very hard to explain. Everyone is coming into Ethiopia.\" \n \nA bloody border war broke out in 1998, matching two of the world's poorest nations. It remains unresolved today. \n \nSamrawit was 1 when her parents risked their lives and hers to flee the country on foot. They did it in daylight. \n \n\"Most of the time people do it in the night-time, but if you have kids, that's very dangerous,\" Adhanom said. \"You're coming through a forest at the border and you have hyenas, tigers, lions on the way. When the hyenas are barking, your kids may cry and you'll be caught because, you see, troops are all over.\" \n \nAl Jazeera English, the now-defunct news service, said last March that Ethiopia has the highest number of refugees in Africa - more than 700,000. At least 100,000 are from Eritrea. Most are confined to one of eight dry, barren camps where only the basics of food and water are available. \n \n\"It's out of a town, so you have no electricity,\" Adhanom said. \"Your house you build yourself with bricks.\" \n \nThe family spent a year in one such camp, but Adhanom was one of the few lucky ones. He was offered a college scholarship by the United Nations High Commissioner of Refugees. That paid for his four years in Shashemene. The family spent a year back in Addis Ababa, where Adhanom did volunteer work with orphans. \n \n\"If you work as a volunteer you can more easily get a job,\" he explained. \n \nAdhanom taught back at the college in Shashemene, where the scholarship provided them living accommodations in a house in town. They applied and qualified for admission into the U.N. refugee program, Destination America. \n \nThey were placed under the auspices of the International Rescue Committee, one of nine resettlement agencies contracted by the U.S. State Department and the one that opened an office in Missoula last summer. \n \nA video on a couple of Facebook pages and now on the Missoulian website shows the new Missoula families from Eritrea singing a Christmas song in their native language at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church. \n \nA State Department report in 2011 said Eritrea is almost evenly divided between Christians and Muslims. Most of those in the high plateau region, including the capital of Asmara, where Adhanom and Reda are from, are the former. \n \nAll those who've landed in Missoula so far practice the Orthodox Tewahedo faith. They've been welcomed here by the Annunciation church and have enjoyed two Christmases in the last few weeks - on Dec. 25 and on Jan. 7, their traditional celebration of the birth of Christ. \n \nThose events have allowed the four Eritrean families to come together and become friends, Adhanom said. \n \nThey gathered at the home of one of the other families on Missoula's southside, along with some of the mentor volunteers from Soft Landing Missoula they've come to know and rely upon. \n \n\"You have food, you have something to drink, you talk, you chat,\" Adhanom said. \"You feel like as if you are with your own family back there in your home country.\" \n \nAfter just three days of school, Samrawit and Ermias are excited. \n \n\"A lot of things they have seen are different,\" their dad said. \"They like that. Of course, they have a barrier with the language, but hopefully they will improve. Samrawit is now getting good. She's trying to speak it. She has a very, very kind and helping friend.\" \n \nThe winter weather has been \"frustrating,\" Adhanom said, but his family has lived in much worse conditions. Helen is anxious to learn to cook American-style, which features much more meat than the Eritrean culture is used to. \n \nFive years from now they'll be eligible to apply for U.S. citizenship, but before that comes one of Montana's best features: summer. \n \n\"I expect I will see myself in a different way that is better than this,\" Adhanom said. \"I see myself walking outside, getting money, becoming a little bit Missoula.\" \n \nAdhanom knows Missoula is not the most diverse town. He and his family have friends from Africa who in the last five years have settled in California, Texas and Las Vegas, where a dark face isn't so out of place. \n \nThe Orthodox church has been the main source of contact with the rest of Missoula for Biniam and Helen, and he said the people there have been \"very, very kind.\" \n \n\"We (hope) the whole community can be like this,\" Adhanom said. \"The community needs to know who we are.\" \n \nThe IRC stakes new refugees with expense money for the first 90 days. It seems inevitable that someday Adhanom will return to his chosen profession as a teacher. Until then, he's eager to get started in whatever job is out there.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"KIM BRIGGEMAN Of The Missoulian"},"topics":[{"name":"Ethiopia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Africa news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Eritrea news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Eritrean refugee family adjusts to winter in Montana","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nez Perce","zipCode":"83501","state":"Idaho","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Lewiston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Lewiston Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169718949","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"740"},"name":"Lewiston Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.lmtribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204352996","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:36Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/lmtribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/96/1969b6af-801d-5cf7-8df1-973409c5d20a/588d8239a1a2f.image.jpg?resize=300%2C224"}],"video":[]}}

UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"}],"wordCount":"309","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195124&p=2kx&v=1&x=DOYUlQnoxFxd1DoJb8UCdg","id":"29396195124","content":"TACOMA - A mysterious ailment that has killed or paralyzed gulls around the Port of Tacoma this week is baffling wildlife biologists. \n \nAbout 50 gulls have been found dead or paralyzed from the neck down. \n \n\"We have never seen a situation like that,\" said state Department of Fish and Wildlife biologist Michelle Tirhi. \"It was a mystery to our biologists and veterinarians.\" \n \nIll birds have been found in a seated position with only their heads moving. \n \n\"One could walk up to them and pick them up,\" Tirhi said. \"They can't fly, they can't walk, they can't move.\" \n \nPort workers began finding dead and sick gulls Sunday night. \n \n\"By the time they got to work on the 23rd they were finding more dead and sick birds,\" Tirhi said. \"Ground zero for this mortality event was Port of Tacoma.\" \n \nIll birds were found at three shipping terminals and other points around Commencement Bay, including Ruston Way, Browns Point, Point Defiance Park and as far north as Kent and Redondo Beach, according to Tirhi. \n \nThe mass die-off is affecting only glaucous gulls - the common gull. \n \n\"This is the thing that's odd to us, they're only gulls,\" Wildlife spokeswoman Madonna Luers said of the fatalities. \n \nThough other species, including crows and ducks, wing around the port, there have been no reports of other species being affected. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:01:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396195072","companies":[{"symbol":"MEC","primary":true,"name":"M&C SpA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"MIL","titleCount":0,"isin":"IT0003955009"},{"symbol":"40S","primary":true,"name":"Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"SES","titleCount":0,"isin":"SG1AD8000002"},{"symbol":"PRRNF","primary":true,"name":"Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"SG1AD8000002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"HOSPICE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"GRANDCHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COURTSHIP & DATING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LIVER DISEASE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"57"},{"name":"BEACHES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"DEATHS & OBITUARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"LIFE FORMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"COMMUNITY COLLEGES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; GEORGIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"TAMPA, FL, USA; UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"554","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195072&p=2kx&v=1&x=rERXiNmuVo0fQXMhaMxcow","id":"29396195072","content":", 68, of Leesburg, Florida passed away peacefully on Thursday, January 26, 2017 at home under hospice care, surrounded by his loving family and friends. Dewey was welcomed into heaven after a courageous 1 1/2 year battle against liver cancer. He was born in Springville, Alabama on March 23, 1948 to Milton Aubrey Waddell and Mary Imogene Rowe Waddell. He moved with his family to Leesburg at 2 years old, graduated from Leesburg High School in 1967, and later received his associates degree from Lake-Sumter Community College. On May 22, 1968 Dewey married the love of his life, Laura Margaret Woodward. They eloped to Cairo Georgia after a short courtship and without the consent of their parents. Laura\u2019s father was concerned about how they would make a living being so young. Dewey assured him they would \u201clive on love\u201d! Well, that they did, and it didn\u2019t take long until Dewey had gained his in-laws approval, love and admiration. With the help of Laura\u2019s parents, Dewey and Laura founded M&C Pipe and Supply, Inc in 1973. Together, Dewey and Laura created a family and circle of friends that were blessed by their endless generosity, joy for life, and immense love. Dewey was an adoring father to his daughter and son-in-law Deann and Tim Coop of St. Petersburg and his son and business partner Dewey \u201cDal\u201d Waddell and his girlfriend Lisa Gasque Bell. He was affectionately known as \u201cBig Daddy\u201d to his six grandchildren: Brandon, Connor and Carson Coop; Trey and wife Kaitlyn, Tyler and Maggie Waddell; and his great granddaughter Allison Waddell. He was also known as \u201cUncle Big Dew\u201d to his nieces and nephews, with whom he had very special relationships: Steve Waddell and wife Kathy of Graceville, Chris Waddell of Graceville, Kim Waddell of Leesburg, Dena McKenna and husband Mike of St. Petersburg, Robyn Mitchell and husband Royce of Edgewater, Eric Lackey and wife Natasha of Tampa, Charles and wife Kristin Struth of Destin, and Jessica Struth of St. Petersburg. He is also survived by his sister-in-law and brother-in-law Charlotte and Mike Struth and his loving and faithful companion Barnelia Woodward. He is preceded in death by Laura, his loving wife of 42 years, his parents, and his brother Steven Lynn Waddell. Dewey loved being surrounded by nature. Two of his favorite places to soak it all in were deep in the woods of Steinhatchee at Po\u2019 Boys Hunt Camp and on the beaches of New Smyrna. He was a highly spiritual and peaceful man. People were drawn to his kind, gentle spirit and delighted in his lighthearted sense of humor. He dedicated his life to relationships. Dewey always saw the good in every human being he encountered. Whether it was an old schoolmate, a business acquaintance, or a stranger in a check-out line, he could make a connection. He had a collection of friends from every generation and walk of life and treasured each and every one. As one friend said, \u201cto know him was to love him\u201d. Memorial service will be held on Saturday February 4th at 2pm at St. James Episcopal Church, with a Reception immediately following at his son's home (Dal Waddell), 801 south 9th St., Leesburg. In lieu of flowers the family suggests contributions to the American Cancer Society (Americancancersociety.org/) or the American Diabetes Foundation (Donations Diabetes Org). Online condolences may be left at www.beyersfuneralhome.com. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"603","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195192&p=2kx&v=1&x=6ghVB4trYeIR6cPAKpkyDA","id":"29396195192","content":"With National Signing Day coming up Wednesday, Colorado\u2019s stake in college athletics keeps getting higher and higher. \n \nThe Denver metro area in particular \u2014 where recruiters have long dogged the lack of elite Division I players \u2014 has seen an increase in talent across the board, with powerhouse athletic schools Valor Christian , Cherry Creek and Regis Jesuit  each having more than ten Division I commits in the Class of 2017. \n \nBehind that upward trend are a number of factors. For one, this place is a boomtown. Colorado was the second-fastest growing state between 2014 and 2015, meaning more kids, a bigger pool of athletes and thus more talent. The explosion of the private training business in the last five years hasn\u2019t hurt either, and plenty of athletes and their families are learning to leverage that training \u2014 and the college connections that come with it \u2014 to advance to the next level. \n \nAnd amid the conditions ripe for both economic and athletic development, Colorado has taken a stranglehold on a couple sports in particular. \n \nThe local girls soccer scene is loaded with top talent, with more than 150 Division I commits in the last three recruiting classes. Top clubs such as Real and Rush continually dominate on a national scale in the Elite Clubs National League, making championship game appearances the norm. That\u2019s not to mention that the future of the United States Women\u2019s National Team, 18-year-old phenom Mallory Pugh, became the youngest American soccer player to score in the Olympic Games last August, just a few months after graduating from Mountain Vista High School. \n Related Articles January 20, 2017   Ex-Ralston Valley hockey standout Tony Salazar battles back from heart attack suffered during first college game   January 15, 2017   D.S.S.T. Stapleton coach Wondame Davis cultivates a family of hoopsters    \nColorado is an epicenter for lacrosse too. It\u2019s partly why legendary college coach Bill Tierney \u2014 who won six titles at Princeton \u2014 decided to ditch the East Coast for the University of Denver, where he has used an influx of homegrown players to build the Pioneers into a national powerhouse. That success is mirrored at the high school level, as the 30-plus Division I commits in the Class of 2017 are defined by guys such as Mountain Vista senior attackman Colin Munro, who in addition to earning a scholarship to North Carolina already gained international recognition by leading the Coquitlam Junior Adanacs to the coveted Minto Cup last summer. \n \nAnd while the state\u2019s two most popular sports, football and boys basketball, are still a long, long way from matching the likes of Texas and California, serious strides have been made in the last decade. On the gridiron, though the majority of Division I talent has become more concentrated within a dozen or so 5A schools, the talent level is increasing nonetheless. The proliferation of the national schedule has helped with that, and Class of 2017 stars such as Valor Christian quarterback Dylan McCaffrey (University of Michigan) and Pomona lineman Jake Moretti (University of Colorado) give promise to more blue-chip recruits in the future. \n \nOn the basketball court, the same trend is becoming evident, with out-of-state tournaments, year-round club ball and names such as 2016 Overland graduate De\u2019Ron Davis (now playing at the University of Indiana) driving more local interest in the game and causing more recruiters to stop by The Centennial State. \n \nAnd as Colorado continues to grow into national prep relevancy \u2014 hockey, wrestling, baseball and softball are on the upswing too \u2014 all local fans who fill the stands can ask is that the athletes keep the hard work coming. If they do that, Colorado could be in the same recruiting realm as Texas and California before you know it.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Kyle Newman"},"topics":[{"name":"Finance latest","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Newman: As National Signing Day looms, Colorado\u2019s recruiting stock continues to rise","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Denver","zipCode":"80202","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Denver","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Denver Post","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169661509","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"35315"},"name":"Denver Post","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.denverpost.com","publisher":"MediaNews Group"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204359262","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:27:15Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:38Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/012a0207-copy.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

an opportunity to pause and look back. \n \nBut leaders at Columbus Regional Hospital will also be looking forward to the next 100 years as they celebrate a century of taking care of patients \u2014 on the Feb. 6 date itself and throughout the anniversary year. \n \nWhile reflecting on the milestone, Jim Bickel \u2014 president and CEO of Columbus Regional Health, a Columbus-based network of health care providers \u2014 wondered a bit what local officials who founded Bartholomew County Hospital in 1917 might think of what the facility has become today. \n \nIt is a community-focused, regional referral health care facility serving a 10-county area, offering specialized care that is more often found in much larger metropolitan areas. \n \n Story continues below gallery  \n    \nDr. Thomas Sonderman \n   \nThe Cancer Center at Columbus Regional Hospital in Columbus, Ind., is now opend, pictured on Thursday, March 24, 2016. The hospital hosted an open house that allowed hospital employees and members of the public to tour the new treatment facility. The hospital hosted an open house that allowed hospital employees and members of the public to tour the new treatment facility. The hospital hosted an open house that allowed hospital employees and members of the public to tour the new treatment facility. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nThe exterior of Columbus Regional Hospital in Columbus, Ind., pictured on Wednesday, Jan. 25, 2017. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nJim Bickel, president and CEO of Columbus Regional Health, talks during an interview with The Republic in his office at Columbus Regional Hospital in Columbus, Ind., Monday, Jan. 23, 2017. Bickel talked about the history of the hospital as it prepares to make it 100th anniversary in February. Mike Wolanin | The Republic \n   \nThis view from the inpatient tower at Columbus Regional Hospital shows flooding off 17th Street in 2008 as school buses lined up to transport patients being evacuated. Submitted \n   \nThe Murphy Tower was re-faced in 1992 during a Columbus Regional Hospital expansion and remodeling. Submitted \n   \nConstruction to the Bartholomew County Hospital pavilion dedicated to former administrator Olive Murphy began in 1966. Submitted \n   \nBartholomew County Hospital opened Feb. 6, 1917. Submitted \n   \nA $1.7 million expansion added two three-story wings, a central heating plan and laundry building to Bartholomew County Hospital, shown in 1953.  Submitted \n   \nThe original Bartholomew County Hospital structure, at right, was razed in 1993. Submitted \n   \nClinical staff and volunteers help transport a patient after high waters in June 2008 forced Columbus Regional Hospital to close. Submitted \n   \nFlooding in June 2008 closed Columbus Regional Hospital for almost five months. Submitted \n   \nThe basement of Columbus Regional Hospital is shown in 2008 after the catastrophic flood that closed the facility for five months. File photo \n   \nA view from above of the flooding in 2008 which caused extensive damage to the hospital. File photo \n   \nA view from above of the flooding in 2008 which caused extensive damage to the hospital. File photo \n   \nEllison \n    Click here to purchase photos from this gallery  \n\u201cI look back and think about the people (in 1917) that didn\u2019t know what the hospital was about, what it was used for. \n \n\u201cI think it really punctuates how far we\u2019ve come over the years,\u201d Bickel said. \n \nA decision by the Bartholomew County Medical Society to pursue building a public hospital 100 years ago showed a great deal of foresight, Bickel said. \n \nWhen it opened, Bartholomew County Hospital had an average of 25 patients a month. Records show that 351 patients were treated in 1917. \n \nToday, the local hospital system serves about 250,000 patients each year. \n \nIn 2016, Columbus Regional Hospital debuted a new cancer treatment center, followed by the opening of a new emergency department, part of a $30 million investment in health care service upgrades. With state-of-the-art equipment upgrades made at the hospital, Bickel said patients from Indianapolis and Cincinnati are traveling to Columbus for treatment. \n \nBickel, who came to the hospital system about 25 years ago, said one of the things that attracted him to the organization was where leaders saw the hospital evolving. \n \n[embedded content] \n \nThat included moving from a predominately county-based facility to a regional one. \n \n\u201cThat really showed some vision,\u201d he said. \u201cThat whole transformation from county hospital to this regional referral center to me was a very profound milestone.\u201d \n \nA new century \n \nAs Columbus Regional Health enters its second century, the challenges are far different and more complex than when the county borrowed $100,000 to build its first hospital, one of the first county hospitals in Indiana. Even though it seems counter intuitive for a facility built to treat illness, Bickel said the ultimate purpose of Columbus Regional Health is to help people from all walks of life live healthier lives. In addition to providing hospital care, the healthcare system is focused on being a good community partner in all its programming and services, as a way to help people take accountability for their health. That means getting involved in socioeconomic issues that people face in the community which affect their health, Bickel said. \n \nOne example is introducing smoking-cessation classes to help people change habits that can lead to serious illnesses. \n \n\u201cHow do we play a role in helping to support those things that will drive the community to be as healthy as possible?\u201d he asked. \n \nAfter attending a Third House session about pre-kindergarten services Jan. 23, Bickel said he sees the challenges in the economic circumstances of the community\u2019s residents and their ability to stay healthy. \n \n\u201cHealth care and education are so intrinsically linked,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have to play a role in that \u2026 We\u2019ve seen the share of health care expenditures increasingly go higher and higher as part of the gross national product and the like, almost to the point it seems insurmountable. We have to get to some of these other root causes that health care traditionally hasn\u2019t had a role in.\u201d \n \nTaking a pro-active stance, Bickel sees the hospital system\u2019s role as making it as easy as possible for people to live the healthiest life possible. \n \n\u201cIt\u201ds not to intervene or to tell people how to lead their lives,\u201d he said. \u201cWe know there are real barriers and challenges out there.\u201d \n \nHelping individuals overcome such obstacles reduces the burden of health care costs and is good for the community\u2019s health in general, he said. \n \nSeamless care \n \nThe hospital system has another goal for the future \u2014 creating a seamless, integrated health care structure within the region to improve care and keep costs down. That has resulted in Columbus Regional Health looking at primary care health providers not only as community partners, but as hospital acquisitions. \u201cWe know across the country there is a shortage of primary care physicians, so we are making deliberate investments in primary care for Columbus Regional Health. Our physician practice \u2014 our medical group \u2014 continues to grow. We\u2019re over 100 providers that are now employed by the health system and we\u2019re seeing that trend continuing, not only here in Indiana but across the country.\u201d \n \nAcquiring the practices and doctor\u2019s services provides a much stronger tie to the health system, Bickel said, describing that trend as a monumental shift from 30 to 40 years ago when independent physicians were the primary healthcare business model. \n \nThat trend continues to develop because of the growing burden on independent physicians to keep up with new technology, such as electronic medical records and infrastructure investments. \n \n\u201cWe want the physicians that are primary care and their office practices part of the system communicating with us in an effort to reduce the fragmentation that\u2019s out there,\u201d Bickel said. \n \nWhat happens in those physician offices and clinics needs to be shared with the hospital system so the patient has a seamless transition from doctor\u2019s office, to hospital to discharge home, he said. \n \nTechnological challenges are looming for the hospital system as well, as even Bartholomew County government is considering adding telemedicine to its insurance plan \u2014 which allows patients to communicate with doctors over the internet rather than in person. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s on our radar to look at,\u201d Bickel said of telemedicine. \n \nWhile patient convenience is important, Columbus Regional Health will want to make sure telemedicine is being used in the most appropriate clinically effective way, he said. \n \n\u201cPhysicians will say it probably has its place,\u201d Bickel said, while recognizing that telemedicine is not appropriate for all medical consultations. \n \n\u201cThose are things we have to work together as a system to figure out,\u201d he said. \n \nAttractive system \n \nMany of the physicians who practice in Bartholomew County and refer patients to Columbus Regional Hospital were first attracted to Columbus initially, said Dr. Thomas Sonderman, the system\u2019s vice president and chief medical officer. After learning about the city\u2019s architectural heritage and experiencing its beauty and the inviting community, Sonderman said many physicians like what they see. Another factor, too, is an evaluation of how the physician\u2019s practice fits into to the health care landscape, Sonderman said. \n \nAre all the needed specialties present? Is there coordination of care? Those are questions that physicians considering Columbus will have, he said. \n \nWhen speaking to medical recruits, Sonderman said the hospital\u2019s independence from the state\u2019s major medical franchises is appealing. \n \nKnowing that Columbus Regional Health is run independently gives physicians a confidence level that decisions are being made locally, and they can have some influence in those decisions, he said. \n \n\u201cMedical care is a team sport,\u201d Sonderman said. \n \nThe recent addition of the new Cancer Care Center and new Emergency Department are also signs to physicians that the hospital wants to be in the forefront when considering capital improvements and technology. \n \nThe latest upgrades show concrete signs that Columbus Regional Hospital is investing in its future, something physicians also consider when choosing where they want to practice, he said. \n \nFull coverage \n \nWhen Bickel arrived in Columbus in 1991, the cancer care initiative was well underway. Looking back, he said that commitment was putting a \u201cstake in the ground\u201d for cancer services locally. As for the emergency department, expansion was mandated by a patient load that was exploding beyond the former facility\u2019s capabilities. \n \nThe former emergency department was sized to handle 20,000 to 25,000 patients a year, but was trying to handle nearly double that capacity when the system created a state-of-the-art facility on the hospital\u2019s east side. \n \nBickel said the emergency department\u2019s usage rate was in part due to a change in patient habits and mindsets. \n \nEmergency rooms, as they were called, were once just used for acute emergency care. But today\u2019s patients are now utilizing hospital emergency departments for routine health procedures and health care \u2014 for matters that could be handled in an urgent care center or primary care physician\u2019s office, Bickel said. \n \nThe patients recognize the convenience of emergency departments being open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, he said. \n \n\u201cThat\u2019s not the most cost-effective side of care. We know that,\u201d Bickel said. \n \nNow the hospital must work upstream so over-utilization of emergency departments can decrease, he said. \n \n\u201cBut for right now, the volume (in the emergency department) has been on a continual upward trajectory,\u201d Bickel said. \n \nColumbus Regional Hospital\u2019s new emergency department was built so that some of its space could be repurposed if eventually it isn\u2019t needed for emergency care, he said. \n \n\u201cI don\u2019t know that we will ever see that. But it\u2019s one of the things we are thinking about.\u201d \n \nBickel pointed to the entire spectrum of Columbus Regional Health services \u2014 oncology, cardiovascular, surgical \u2014 and how they work together to help patients receive care close to home. \n \nIn the early 2000s, the hospital system launched into providing open-heart and bypass surgeries after bringing a cardiac program to the region. \n \nColumbus Regional Hospital has a catheterization lab, with not just diagnostic, but interventional capabilities. \n \n\u201cYou have a blockage in your artery, we go into the cath lab, open that up, put in a stent,\u201d Bickel said. \u201cThat service is important in this region because we\u2019re the only interventional cath lab outside of the major metropolitan areas \u2026 the speed in which you get into the cath lab and get that vessel opened up, the better the outcome for the patient.\u201d \n \nColumbus Regional Health has partnered with IU Health to provide cardiac surgery services at the hospital, tapping into that health system\u2019s bench depth and clinical expertise \u2014 without patients having to travel to a metropolitan area, Bickel said. \n \nFuture plans \n \nZack Ellison, who leads the Columbus Regional Health board of trustees, said the county continues to focus on investing in the latest technology and capital improvements for the hospital. Describing Columbus Regional as the crown jewel for the county and Columbus, Ellison said the nonprofit hospital has continued to be economically healthy enough to provide money that can be re-invested in the hospital itself and its technology. He credited management of the hospital over the years with its continued success, along with the county\u2019s commitment to keep it locally operated. \n \n\u201cLook around to the counties around us, and you will see county hospitals being sold,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m proud of the community for keeping our hospital a county-owned hospital,\u201d Ellison said. \n \nWhen speaking to new employees in a group, Bickel said he always makes sure to talk about the hospital system\u2019s values and how they are demonstrated in the community. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s what makes Columbus, Columbus \u2014 everybody pitching in. It\u2019s great to pause and celebrate that,\u201d Bickel said. \u201cAnd we\u2019re looking forward to the next 100 years.\u201d \n \nColumbus Regional Health milestones \n  \n1915: Bartholomew County bonds for $100,000 to construct a new hospital north of 17th Street and east of Haw Creek in Columbus. \n \n1917: The three-story Bartholomew County Hospital opens with 32 bedsand 25 employees. Its first patients are admitted on Feb. 6. \n \n1930: The Hattie S. Kirkpatrick Memorial Nurses Home, which is housing for nurses, is established on the northwest side of the hospital. \n \n1945: An addition on the south wing is added, increasing hospital capacity to 75 beds. \n \n1949: Bartholomew County Commissioners approve plans for a $780,000 expansion, increasing capacity to 129 beds. \n \n1953: The hospital completes a $1.7 million expansion with additions including two three-story wings; the number of beds is expanded to 142. \n \n1959: The hospital expands to add 39 more beds, remodeling the second floor and emergency areas at a cost of $911,000. \n \n1968: $3.7 million in bonds are issued to build Murphy Pavilion, a five-story in-patient unit of 108 beds in honor of former administrator Olive Murphy, who retired in 1967 as hospital administrator after 28 years of service. \n \n1972: The hospital opens a 10-bed intensive coronary-care unit. \n \n1973: The hospital renovates its children\u2019s ward. \n \n1976-1978: Plans are announced for a $7.2 million expansion adding two floors to the Murphy Pavilion and ambulatory services, including radiology and laboratory. \n \n1979: The hospital partners with Lifeline Helicopter in Indianapolis to provide local service. \n \n1981: Labor and delivery rooms are established on a pilot basis. \n \n1983: Patients are admitted to a new psychiatric ward. \n \n1984: The hospital reclassifies as a regional referral center and a paramedic program begins. \n \n1988: Bartholomew County Hospital and Quinco Consulting Center affiliate to expand and improve mental health services. \n \n1990: Ground is broken on a $40 million expansion and renovation project which includes a cancer treatment center and birthing center. \n \n1991: The hospital adopts a smoke-free policy. \n \n1992-1994: Bartholomew County Hospital changes its name to Columbus Regional Hospital and celebrates completion of a renovation project that added new pavilions, front lobby, gift shop, dining room, physicians office building and renovations and additions to the main patient tower. The Cancer Center opens. \n \n1995: The Breast Health Center opens in the Haw Creek Medical Office Building, and PromptMed Immediate Care Center opens on 25th Street. \n \n1996: Volunteers in Medicine clinic opens offering health care to the uninsured and underinsured in Bartholomew County. \n \n2001: The hospital\u2019s website is launched. \n \n2004: A Picture Archiving and Communications System is implemented and a new linear accelerator begins delivering radiation therapy in cancer treatment. The North Medical Office Building is built. Our Hospice of South Central Indiana opens an inpatient facility on the east end of the main hospital campus. \n \n2008: Plans are announced for a new emergency department and patient tower. A record flood closes the hospital for five months. All employees remained on paid staff during the closure and the hospital coordinated patient care for residents in the area through surrounding regional health systems. \n \n2011: A flood wall is build around the entire main hospital campus. The health system changes its name to Columbus Regional Health. \n \n2012: Surgical Services begins using the da Vinci Si Robotic Surgical System. \n \n2013: WellConnect opens in downtown Columbus. Columbus Regional Health becomes an official cosponsor of the Mill Race Marathon. \n \n2014: Inspire Health Partners is created by a partnership through Columbus Regional Health, Schneck Medical Center and SIHO. Plans for an expanded Cancer Center and new Emergency Department are announced. \n \n2016: The Cancer Center expansion is completed with state-of-the-art radiation equipment and physicians. The new Emergency Department is double the size of the previous facility. Volunteers in Medicine changes its name to VIMCare Clinic and opens in the former hospital emergency department space. \n \n\u2014 Source: Columbus Regional Health \n  \nPhysician practices under CRH umbrella \n  \nColumbus ENT and Allergy \n \nColumbus Family Medicine \n \nColumbus Gynecology and Adult Medicine \n \nColumbus Internal Medicine \n \nColumbus Pediatrics \n \nSouthern Indiana \nComing Feb. 5 \n  \nA magazine detailing Columbus Regional Hospital\u2019s 100-year history will be included in The Republic on Feb. 5. \n \nThe section, \u201cOne Hundred Years of Caring,\u201d includes a look back over the century of care and provides a chapter on where the health system is headed in the future. \n  \nColumbus Regional Hospital by the numbers \n  \nThen \n \n32: Number of beds in Bartholomew County Hospital, which opened on Feb. 6, 1917. \n \n25: Average number of patients admitted monthly in 1917. \n \n351: Patients treated in the hospital\u2019s first year. \n \n$69,442: Final cost for the first hospital building. \n \nNow \n \n250,000: Number of patients Columbus Regional Health cares for each year. \n \n2,500: Columbus Regional Health employees. \n \n$317 million: Annual operating expenses for the health system. \n \n\u2014 Source: Columbus Regional Health","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Julie McClure"},"topics":[],"title":"After 100 years Volunteers will be \nresponsible for cleaning the areas and side streets throughout Bayshore \nBlvd that will be used as both the float staging area and parade route, \nfocusing on both trash and recyclable items.  Of Note \u2013 Both Dan and \nChristine Fisher, founders of both Tampa Bay Dive Against Debris and the \nDay After Gasparilla Cleanup, will be flying in from Germany to attend \nthis cleanup.  Dan is currently working overseas supporting United \nStates European Command. \n \nWHEN: Sunday, January 29, 9:30am to 12:30pm . \n \nWHERE: Volunteers will meet at the signup tent located at the Tampa \nWoman\u2019s Club, 2901 Bayshore Blvd, \nat 9:00am for a brief orientation. \n \nWHY: Much of the debris that makes its way in the waters along Bayshore \nBoulevard during Gasparilla season comes directly from Gasparilla \nactivities, such as the parades. Day After Gasparilla cleanup conducts a \ncleanup along Bayshore Boulevard and the associated side streets the day \nafter the Gasparilla Adult Parade of Pirates. Volunteers clean the areas \nand side streets throughout Bayshore Blvd which were used as both the \nfloat staging area and parade route, focusing on both trash and recyclable \nitems. AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HOUSTON, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; VICTORIA, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"450","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195276&p=2kx&v=1&x=UEAMQczYkryajhu-pB1vlQ","id":"29396195276","content":"Donald Trump's Muslim ban banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families, says Melbourne's Somalian community. \n\nIt's a place that sings of the Australian summer: lemon-scented gums, the trill of cicadas, sand underfoot and a sliver of navy ocean on the horizon.\n\nHussein Haraco and 35 other men from Melbourne's Somalian community had driven down for a weekend at an Anglesea holiday camp.\n\nThey were there to talk leadership; how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:40Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396195358","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SCHOLARSHIPS & GRANTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"JUNK FOODS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"MOUNTAINS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"HIGH SCHOOLS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"88"},{"name":"CREATIVE WRITING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"PSYCHOLOGY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"64"},{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"}],"wordCount":"948","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396195358&p=2kx&v=1&x=hZadBeA0St7mKI2PiZvK6g","id":"29396195358","content":"Despite that headline, this is not a political column! It has nothing to do with the election, the president, the Congress or the White House.\n\nNow that you're breathing a collective sigh or relief, do read on.\n\nMy first born, Samantha, who is 18, really has a pretty clear idea of what she wants out of life.\n\nShe sure didn't get that from me. I still don't know!\n\nShe got her acceptance letter from Fairleigh Dickinson this past week. She wants to study engineering, in keeping with her tradition of being on the award-winning Mount Olive High School robotics team for the past four years. She knows what she wants to study, and even knows that she wants to come back to the high school as a mentor, to work with the up and coming robotics team kids.\n\nShe's busy looking for women in engineering scholarships, with an impressive \"resume\" of having been key to the robotics team at the high school for four years.\n\nShe's got it all kind of figured out. I told her last week that I was impressed, and that I was precisely the opposite!\n\nNow, let's talk about me 25 and 30 years ago.\n\nI had no idea what I wanted to do. Zero. I was terrible at math. I was terrible at science.\n\nBut I guess I could write pretty well, even back then. Still, where to go with that? I just had no clue. No ideas at all.\n\nIn high school, I wrote absolutely nothing for the Lenape Valley newspaper. Nothing. It never even would have dawned on me. I remember one time being asked what my favorite junk food was. And my name made it into the school newspaper. I thought that was a pretty big thrill. But other than that, my only writing experience was in creative writing. I remember once writing a kind of gruesome horror short story.\n\nThe result of that was a trip to the school psychologist, just to make sure I was operating on all thrusters.\n\nWhen it came time for college, I knew I had to do it, or should do it, but I wasn't enthused. I wasn't looking forward to much of anything, except when the next Star Trek movie was coming out. (Come to think of it, I'm still often in that mindset!) I was just kind of going through the motions, not really knowing what I wanted to do. I never dreamed back then that this keyboard I'm sitting at now and composing this literary masterpiece would ever play such a big role in my life.\n\nMy mom had to beg me to take a typing class. And yes, those were the days when it was still a \"typing\" class. I was hesitant. \"What will I ever need that for?\" I recall asking.\n\nOut of high school, I quickly liked the notion of attending County College of Morris. Not only was it a highly rated school, but they had a good journalism program. Kind of by default, I chose my major.\n\nWhat would I later do it it I had no idea. But, CCM was close enough to Byram, and would still leave me lots of time to pursue other interests? Like what? Good question! Well, attending Star Trek conventions. Going to movies. Visiting Circle Lanes in Ledgewood You know, that really important kind of stuff.\n\nThe point was, I just didn't that much care. And I certainly wasn't excited about school. I didn't totally hate it. I just wasn't excited. It was kind of just there. I have always been afraid of change, so it took some getting used to.\n\nBut, I fell in kind of comfortably at CCM. Part of the requirement of the journalism curriculum was to choose a \"beat\", about which I would be required to regularly submit an article. And it wasn't easy! I wound up with the social sciences department! Talk about boring. I can remember pestering Jackie Crimmel, the department secretary, for a story idea every week. Years later, I'd be after her for quotes and comments again, when I got this job and found out she was on the Roxbury school board. We always joked about the days I'd visit her office and ask \"what's going on\" in the exciting field of the social sciences department.\n\nTypically, my story would be something like \"Teacher to revise sociology text book\" or some other equally exciting subject.\n\nIt wasn't until I wrote my first-person account of meeting President Richard Nixon outside his home in Saddle River that things started to get exciting. I can remember that week's paper, and all the teachers talking about it, and kids asking me was I the one who made that trip. It was fun. I started to like having my stuff read.\n\nLater, commuting to William Paterson, I again didn't write much for the student newspaper, but I began freelancing for a now defunct newspaper covering meetings in Byram, Stanhope and Netcong, mostly.\n\nUnlike the other kids in class, I was actually out there doing it. While the professors were talking about the life of a journalist, I was experiencing it. That was kind of neat. I remember one professor critiquing one of my masterpieces in front of the class. That didn't go too well. I like to think I've gotten better.\n\nAnd then, out of school, I found Roxbury. And Roxbury found me. It has been a pretty happy union for the past two decades.\n\nAnd now, I count Harding, and all of the towns The Citizen covers as \"my towns.\" And I have to admit, it has been pretty enjoyable.\n\nJust don't ask me what I want to do next.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"MIKE CONDONEditor"},"topics":[],"title":"AS I SEE IT: A clear path ahead, and a total lack of one","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Rock Island","zipCode":"61265","state":"Illinois","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Moline","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"The Progress","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169670235","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"The Progress","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://newjerseyhills.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204363246","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:28:40Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/newjerseyhills.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/e9/6e908f08-f907-5c7a-b128-a8e36b98cff6/5874fd8456630.image.jpg?resize=200%2C297"}],"video":[]}}
