McKayla Alves served as vocalist, while Aaron Alves played guitar. \n\nThe reception was held at the home of the bride\u2019s father. \n\nAfter a wedding trip to Savannah, Ga., the couple will reside in Seven Springs. \n\nA rehearsal dinner, hosted by the grooms parents, was held at Ribeyes Steakhouse. \n\nVarious showers and parties were held for the couple, including a miscellaneous shower at Northeast Free Will Baptist Church given by Sue Jones, Karen Cox, Wanda Howard and Eileen Whitfield Nov. 20; a miscellaneous shower given by church friends at the home of Sue Beaman Nov. 27; a gift card shower given by the Parks family Dec. 4; a monogram shower given by Chelsie Spurgeon at her home Dec. 10; a Christmas shower Dec. 18 given by Hayley and Ava Ginn and Brenda Kearney at the Ginn home; and a bridal luncheon given Jan. 21 by Gloria Flowers at her home. \n\nBy News-Argus Staff\n\nPublished in Weddings on January 29, 2017 1","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Management news","group":"Business"}],"title":"Parks-Kearney","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wayne","zipCode":"27532","state":"North Carolina","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Goldsboro","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Goldsboro News-Argus","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169719013","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3"},"name":"Goldsboro News-Argus","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newsargus.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204485868","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:29:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:29:57Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393029859","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"VEHICLE TRAFFIC","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"NATIONAL PARKS","domains":["IND"],"score":"66"},{"name":"SPEED LIMITS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"TRAVELER SAFETY & SECURITY","domains":["IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FARMERS & RANCHERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"74"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"733","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396201526&p=2kx&v=1&x=XzRBhE5vO1jIniNANrZImg","id":"29396201526","content":"Enlargephoto   \nJim Mimiaga/The Journal \n \nMore than 100 people showed up at a Colorado Department of Transportation meeting about proposals for the County Road BB-U.S. Highway 491 intersection at Pleasant View. \n    \nP leasant View residents and the Colorado Department of Transportation are at an impasse on how to improve the intersection at U.S. Highway 491 and County Road BB. \n   \nA decision is expected soon, with one option that would close the intersection. \n   \nCDOT\u2019s preliminary plan is to rebuild the intersection into a restrictive \u201cright-in, right-out\u201d turn to prevent left turns onto County Road BB and the busy highway. \n   \nThe intersection is at the bottom of a hill, and visibility of oncoming highway traffic falls short of federal standards. It is rated as one of the top six intersections that need safety improvements in Region 5, which covers 15 counties in Southwest Colorado. \n   \nCDOT wants to redirect traffic to County Road CC for travelers heading west off the highway to the Pleasant View community and on to farms, oil and gas fields, and nearby national monuments. Road CC intersects with U.S. 491 a mile north of Road BB, and has favorable sight distance. \n   \n\u201cThe BB intersection has been vetted as a priority and is in need of safety improvement, and we\u2019re obligated to do something about it for the safety of the traveling public,\u201d CDOT program manager Ed Archuleta, said Wednesday during a packed meeting at the Pleasant View School. \n   \nBut locals are heavily opposed to any major change to the Road BB intersection because it is considered a key access point for residents, farmers and ranchers. \n   \nThey say improved safety signage, a left turn lane and lower speed limit would mitigate the danger. Also, concern was expressed that redirecting traffic to Road CC would send it all by the Pleasant View school, causing a safety hazard. \n   \nResidents hotly contested CDOT\u2019s claims that the Road BB intersection contributes to a lot of accidents. \n   \n\u201cHow many were actually caused by the intersection?\u201d asked one resident. \n   \n\u201cMoving access to Road CC, there will still be accidents,\u201d said another. \u201cYou can\u2019t fix stupid.\u201d \n   \nResident Merle Root said restricting or closing the intersection \u201cwill hurt local residents.\u201d She has lived at the intersection for 30 years and has seen animals cause more accidents than the problematic intersection. \n   \nIncreased traffic CDOT records show nine vehicle accidents at the intersection, including one fatality, since 1996. Five of the nine are listed as intersection-related. \n   \nHighway use continues to increase, Archuleta said, making accidents there in the future more likely. In 2015, there were 4,300 annual daily traffic counts on U.S. 491, compared with 3,900 in 2012. He said cutting down the highway hill at the Road BB intersection to improve sight distance would be cost-prohibitive. \n   \n\u201cIt would cost at least $4 million, which is the entire budget for road safety improvements for 15 counties,\u201d he said. \u201cThe transportation budget is limited.\u201d \n   \n\u201cThe simple solution would be to drop the speed limit there from 65 mph to 45 mph,\u201d responded local resident Joe Black. \n   \nThe CDOT deal CDOT, which controls the intersection right of way, offered the county a solution, which is also heavily resisted by the locals. \n   \nCDOT has offered the county $630,000 to close the Road BB intersection. By closing the intersection, the county could spend the money to improve Pleasant View area roads. Areas under consideration include chip-sealing sections of Roads 15, 16, CC and 10, and building a truck turnaround at Road 15.5 to serve the livestock loading chute and corrals. \n   \n\u201cIt\u2019s a chunk of money that will benefit the community,\u201d said county road supervisor Rob Englehart. \u201cIf the county does not close the road, we won\u2019t get the funds, and CDOT probably puts in the right-in, right-out.\u201d \n   \nA public hearing on the matter will be held at 1:30 p.m. on Monday, Jan. 30, in the county commission room. At the hearing, the commissioners could decide whether the Road BB intersection at the highway will be closed or not. \n   \nCommissioner James Lambert said he believes CDOT will move forward with the right-in, right-out alternative if the county does not shut the road. But regarding his vote on whether to close it, he said he sent out letters to Road BB and Road CC residents asking them what they want. \n   \n\u201cWhatever the majority is will be how I vote on the matter,\u201d he said. \n   \nIf the traffic is diverted down Road CC, the Montezuma-Cortez Re-1 School District and county said they will work together to install safety fencing around the school and traffic warnings.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"CDOT intersection plan might come down to the money","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montezuma","zipCode":"81321","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Cortez","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Cortez Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169876103","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"222"},"name":"Cortez Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.cortezjournal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204486699","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:29:57Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Europe Online           Berlin (dpa) - The leaders of Germany\u2018s Social Democrats are set to back former European Parliament president Martin Schulz as the SPD\u2018s challenger to Chancellor Angela Merkel in September\u2018s national election. \nThe leaders\u2018 decision on Sunday at a conclave in Berlin to formally nominate Schulz as the SPD standard-bearer as well as party chief comes after the announcement by Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel that he was standing down as party chairman. \n\nThe left-leaning party\u2018s hopes for the September election have been raised by the prospects of Schulz taking over, after Gabriel trailed badly behind Merkel in opinion polls. \n\nA poll published on Friday showed support for the SPD as having jumped by 3 percentage points since the start of the year to 24 per cent. \n\nIf Germans could directly elect their chancellor, Merkel would garner 44 per cent of the vote, while Schulz would pick up 40 per cent, according to the survey drawn up by pollsters Forschungsgruppe Wahlen for the German public broadcaster ZDF. \n\nThe survey of 1303 voters found that SPD\u2018s supporters were upbeat about their new chancellor candidate with 71 per cent saying they hoped that Gabriel\u2018s decision to stand aside for Schulz would improve the party\u2018s chances. \n\nHowever, the poll also underlined the uphill battle that Schulz faces in turning around his party\u2018s political fortunes and even trying to topple Merkel, who is making a bid for a fourth term on September 24. \n\nThe ZDF survey showed the SPD is still 12 percentage points behind Merkel\u2018s conservative Christian Democrats (CDU) and their Bavarian-based Christian Social Union (CSU) allies, which mustered 36 per cent of the vote. \n\nAfter this weekend\u2018s nomination, the SPD is expected to then formally back the 61-year-old Schulz at a conference set for the middle of March. Myers punches the air in celebration as Thee Auld Floozie claims Group I success in the Thorndon Mile. \n   \nThee Auld Floozie's first Group I victory could earn her a another start in the top flight or a well deserved break. \n \nMore than 24 hours after her scorching win in Saturday's Thorndon Mile at Trentham, Cambridge trainer Stephen Marsh remained undecided on what her next step will be. \n \nA five-year-old daughter of Mastercraftsman, Thee Auld Floozie holds a nomination for the $400,000 Group I Herbie Dyke Stakes (2000m) at Te Rapa but there is no decision on whether she will take her spot at this stage. \n \n\"I'm still thinking about the Herbie Dyke, there's 400,000 reasons to be there, but I'm not sure,\" Marsh said.  \n \n  \n   \n   \n   \n   \n   \n \n\"I'm considering sending her for a break, we'll see in the next few days.\" \n \nThe Group I scalp is a huge feather in the cap of part owners John and Sue Young, who bred Thee Auld Floozie out of their good race mare Thee Auld Hussie. \n \nRosie Myers gave Thee Auld Floozie a perfect trip on the rail before she hit the go button and let the mare's explosive turn of foot finish the job off. \n \nThee Auld Floozie beat home Prince Of Passion by a length and a half with the same margin back to Abidewithme in third. \n \nMarsh started four runners in the race with Serious Satire finishing fifth and Seize The Moment (11th) and Ruud Not Too (14th) finishing back in the field. \n \nIn the other feature at Trentham, a potential New Zealand Oaks contender was unveiled when the Murray Baker and Andrew Forsman-trained Nicoletta scored a short head victory in the Group III Desert Gold Stakes. \n \nNicoletta beat home Devise with another Baker-Forsman runner Bonneval a further one and a half lengths She spent most of her adult life living in Hiram. \n \nShe graduated from John Marshall High School in Cleveland in 1939, and after graduation, she was a nurse\u2019s aide for several years in the Cleveland area during the World War II era. \n \nKatherine was a member of St. Ambrose Catholic Church in Garrettsville. \n \nKatherine loved to sew and one year made all the cheerleading uniforms at both Crestwood and James A. Garfield high schools. All of her grandchildren were able to wear the nicest flannel shirts. Her sewing ability was so good that her children would sometimes wear the best and most fashionable clothes in the area. She spent much time at Crafty Ann\u2019s in Garrettsville, doing things like painting and needlepoint work. She made many Christmas ornaments and other craft items for her children and grandchildren. She had the ability to take old, used items such as milk cans and broken pieces of roof slate and turn them into beautiful decorations for family homes. \n \nKatherine also enjoyed playing golf with her friends. She never missed any of her children\u2019s or grandchildren\u2019s sporting events. She devoted her life to being a loving mom and grandma. Family was her life! \n \nPreceding her in passing was her husband, William Kothera, to whom she was married for 65 years. \n \nKatherine is survived by her sons, Lee (Sandy) of Hiram and Clark (Sharyn) of Charlotte; daughters, Kris (Mitch) Collins of Newton Falls and Cathy Morehouse of Texas; grandchildren, Pam, Greg, Kim, Cody, Connie, Curt, Carla, Kelliann, Kassi, Kortni, Kirsti, Katie and Steve; and great-grandchildren, Lindsay, Luke, Stephanie, Nikki, Justin, Cameron, Maggie, Laney, Ella, Clara, Kayla, Carson, Sophia, Damien and Mason. \n \nShe was preceded in death by her husband, William; and siblings, twin brother, Edward; as well as a sister, Louise. \n \nAny contributions should be made to the Hiram Firefighters Association. \n \nArrangements have been entrusted to Mallory-DeHaven-Carlson Funeral Home. She grew up on Long Island, N.Y., surrounded by a large Sicilian family. \n \nShe was predeceased by her husband, Frank GJ; daughter, Patricia; and her brother, Thomas, who passed prior to her birth. \n \nAfter graduating from Mepham High School, she attended Buffalo State College, where she met her husband, Frank. They married and moved to College Park, Md., where he then completed his degree. They moved to Warren, where Eleanor lived for 30 years before returning to Maryland. \n \nAfter their four children were in school, Eleanor returned to college and earned her bachelor\u2019s degree in education. She briefly taught and then worked at the Warren Public Library until she retired in 1998. Eleanor went further to earn her master of library science from Kent State University. To Eleanor, working at the library was a job she loved so much that she would have done it for free. \n \nTwo of Eleanor\u2019s greatest pleasures were reading and traveling. She was known to finish, on average, two books a week. Historical fiction was her favorite genre. Eleanor traveled extensively throughout her life, first with her husband, and after his death, with various tour groups. Europe was her favorite destination. She traveled from the fjords of Norway to the sunny south of Spain. Throughout the years, there were two trips that she always said were her favorites. The first was a trip to Germany and Austria with her daughters, Tina, Beth and daughter-in-law, Maridy. The other was a cruise to the Greek Isles with her daughter, Beth. Pictures of Eleanor from these trips highlight her adventurous spirit. \n \nAfter retiring from the Warren Public Library, she moved to Annapolis, Md., where she worked part-time at the Anne Arundal Public Library and Borders Book Store. Reading and books were a passion she obviously could not live without. She always said that she continued working past retirement so that she could continue to travel. \n \nEleanor is survived by her son, Michael (Adriana) of Maryland; daughters, Tina (Maridy) Boyer of Concord and Beth Horn of Groveport; grandchildren, Jennifer Snell, Jennifer Horn (Matt) Neff, Jaremie (Susan) Horn, Josh (Amanda) Horn, Jodi Horn and Jacob Horn; and 10 great-grandchildren. \n \nThe family wishes to thank the staff of Morningside Assisted Living of Concord, Kestrel Ridge Family Home and Universal Healthcare, for the excellent care she received in the past eight years. \n \nAccording to the family\u2019s wishes, there will be no services. born June 20, 1923, in Trento, Italy, the son of the late Pangrazio Louis and Guiditta Theresa Raoss Lorenzi, and emigrated to the United States when he was 15 months old. He was raised in Nuremberg, Pa., and had been a Howland resident for 46 years. \n \nNorio served as a gunner\u2019s mate in the U.S. Navy in the European Theatre during World War II. He retired in 1986 from General Motors in Lordstown, where he worked as a painter in the maintenance department for 27 years. He also was a licensed Realtor in the area for many years. \n \nNorio was a member of VFW Post 1090 in Warren, where he had served as chaplain. Lordstown, passed away Friday, Jan. 27, 2017 surrounded by his large family at Trumbull Memorial Hospital. Google+ \n  \n\n Leicester to keep hold of Slimani unless Tianjin go big  Leicester City have reportedly knocked back advances from Tianjin Quanjian for Algerian striker Islam Slimani.  \nThe 28-year-old joined the English champions from Sporting in the summer, and has since netted six goals in all competitions. \n\nAccording to Sky Sports News, the Foxes have snubbed a £38m bid from Tianjin for Slimani, and they are unlikely to sell unless they receive an extraordinary offer this month. \n\nSlimani has not been able to live up to his hype at the Premier League holders, but he still remains crucial to Claudio Ranieri 's plans to keep his side in the top flight. \n\nThe Algerian international recently returned from the African Cup of Nations after his country's exit, but he is unlikely to play for some while due to a groin problem. \n\nTianjin have already recruited the likes of Axel Witsel and Alexandre Pato from Zenit St Petersburg and Villareal respectively this month.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Sri Aswin"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: soccer news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Leicester turn down Islam Slimani bid","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","countryCode":"GB","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"eyefootball","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169678181","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"eyefootball","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Sports","Soccer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.eyefootball.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://plus.google.com/108239674160524816579?rel=author"],"sequenceId":"695204498286","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:29:59Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:23:27Z","duplicateGroupId":"29393675185","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TERRORIST ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"AL-QAEDA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"TERRORISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ARMIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ISLAMIC STATE IN IRAQ & THE LEVANT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"JOURNALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"PRESS CONFERENCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"DICTATORSHIPS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"PRIME MINISTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"ARMED FORCES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"59"},{"name":"AFGHANISTAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"99"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"NOURI AL-MALIKI","domains":["PEO"],"score":"66"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BARACK OBAMA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"1058","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396201830&p=2kx&v=1&x=L7uNVFvpTlByN0tgalkHkw","id":"29396201830","content":"by Umar Sa\u2019ad Hassan \n \nPresident Donald Trump has promised to get Americans off welfare by rebuilding America with American labour. He has promised an end to the era where their borders were open to countries stealing their companies, making their products and destroying their jobs. America will no longer enhance foreign industries at the detriment of its own and will no longer spend trillions overseas while its infrastructure continues to decay.It will not protect other countries\u2019 borders at the expense of its own and will not empower other armies while it gets depleted. \n -- \n  \nTrump is just the right man to finally make the world understand that America doesn\u2019t owe anybody anything and there couldn\u2019t be a better time than now when its gestures are not only being taken for granted but also used to paint it the villain. \n \nAs of this time last year, the United States campaign against ISIS tagged Operation Inherent Resolve had gulped $6.2 billion at a princely rate of approximately $480,000 an hour and the Pentagon was asking for an additional $7.5 billion to keep on fighting the ISIS. That was all just a year and half into the campaign and before the terrorist group made massive forays into Afghanistan and Libya. But what has it gotten in return? Castigations and denigrations that defy human reasoning. \n \nPresident Trump\u2019s predecessor, Barack Obama has been blamed for the rise of the ISIS by withdrawing US troops from Iraq in 2011 but it is important to note that the Status of Forces agreement made by the Bush administration set a 2011 withdrawal date. This much was said by Bush when he held a famous joint press conference with the then Iraqi prime minister, Nouri Al Maliki and moments after saying that, he was stoned by an Iraqi journalist. That was the extent to which most Iraqis had grown to abhor the United States presence in their country. They saw the US troops as illegitimate occupiers and causes of civilian deaths. Al Maliki summed up the sentiment when he said: \u201cThe incomplete sovereignty and presence of foreign troops have been the most dangerous, most complicated and most burdensome legacy since the dictatorship. Iraq should get rid of them to prevent its young democratic experiment\u201d. \n \nThe US merely complied with the wishes of the Iraqi people by pulling the stops on a war that had cost it $1trillion at that time, so I find it utterly disgusting to hear people say they left earlier than they should. The oppression of the Sunni minority by the Shiite majority after the Americans left ensured an emerging ISIS had a lot of sympathisers from the Sunnis who had been instrumental in helping the US troops fight Al Qaeda. There have been many reports on how complacent the Iraqi army got when they were left to stand on their own and this made the ISIS grow in confidence. It is not Obama\u2019s fault that the Sunni/Shiite conflict had been going on for centuries or that Al-Maliki rubber stamped the oppression of the minority Sunni after the US left and killed hundreds of those who dared to protest neither is it his that the Iraqis didn\u2019t make the over $20 billion spent by the US in rebuilding its armed forces just a year after its withdrawal, count. \n \nThe start of the Syrian civil war in 2011 meant the ISIS had more than enough land across the border to comfortably grow in. While I am not disputing the fact that the US may have covertly armed unrecognized forces severally to help fight a common enemy and that this could very much be said to have created a situation where weapons were left in the hands of people very prone to being swayed by the ISIS,it is important to understand its motive which simply put is, helping a people fight a just cause. \n \nTake Syria, for example, where Bashir Al Assad had ruled for about 10 years as at the time of the famous revolt in some Arab nations against the perpetual leadership in 2010 popularly referred to as the Arab Spring.He had taken over from his father who had ruled for 29 years and Assad was the most vicious of all the rulers turned against by their own people. He went as far as dispersing protests with life bullets and attacking his own people with chemical weapons. It was obvious the war had taken a new dimension and arming and training those willing to stand up to the government was a great service to the Syrian people. That a lot of Syrian fighters with arms thought the ISIS cause a worthier one at some point is not America\u2019s fault. Here in Nigeria, when a lot of people in the South East and South South turned to armed robbery after the civil war because of the abundance of arms in the region, governments fought hard to curb the scourge rather than blaming who was supplying the Biafrans arms during the war. \n \nAs elementary as this may sound, it still remains the truth. The problem lies first with the extremists, their warped understanding of Islam and the individuals and countries supporting them. Terrorism has been helped by the advancement of the social media which has allowed the extremists prey on vulnerable minds and show off their might more easily.Then you also have the fact that the weaker groups are now uniting with the stronger ones instead of fighting themselves. \n \nThey may be a plethora of other reasons why terrorism is growing but it is certainly not because of the United States of America.The world owes it loads of gratitude for its efforts at making it a better place and not condemnation. \n \nTrump is the new man on board and he has promised to spend less on helping others fight their wars.It makes sense if you consider the money that has being pumped into that by previous governments and what he wants to use funds for.The new \u2018big brother\u2019 wants everybody to fend for themselves and it has dawned on quite a number of people especially those who kept hating the US for helping them that America doesn\u2019t owe anybody anything. \n \nOp\u2013ed AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"BALEARIC ISLANDS, SPAIN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"},{"name":"ROGER FEDERER","domains":["PEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ANDY MURRAY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"SERENA WILLIAMS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"RAFAEL NADAL","domains":["PEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"VENUS WILLIAMS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"NOVAK DJOKOVIC","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"642","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396202155&p=2kx&v=1&x=i7aQrGfOawHinyTvIWyDLg","id":"29396202155","content":"Preview: Roger Federer and Rafa Nadal take to Rod Laver Arena to reprise one of the great sporting rivalries of the modern age on Sunday, a fitting climax to an Australian Open which has sent tennis back to the future. \n \nAfter the thirtysomething Williams sisters play their own throwback final on Saturday, Federer and Nadal will meet in a grand slam final for the first time in more than five years. \n \nTheir ninth meeting in a grand slam final is all the sweeter for being so unexpected. \n \nLast October, as both men have recalled this week, Federer travelled to Mallorca for the opening of his friend's new tennis academy. \n \nThe Swiss was on \"one leg\" after knee surgery and the Spaniard still hampered by the wrist injury that wrecked his 2016 season. \n \n\"At that moment, for sure we never thought that we had the chance to be in a final again, and especially in the first of the year,\" recalled Nadal. \n \n\"Both of us I think worked very hard to be where we are. It's great that we are again in a moment like this.\" \n \nAs Nadal and Federer arrived at Melbourne Park as ninth and 17th seeds, therefore, the first drafts of the obituaries of two great sporting careers were being prepared. \n \nThey were hurriedly dropped back into the files, however, as it became apparent the duo were playing vintage tennis: Federer all fluidity and peerless shot-making, Nadal at his brutal best from the baseline. \n \nThe early departures of reigning champion Novak Djokovic and top seed Andy Murray, the players who had joined Federer and Nadal to make up the \"Big Four\", then opened up the path to a grand final reunion. \n \nAlthough it has often felt more like 2007 than 2017 at Melbourne Park this week, even great champions are not immune to the ravages of time. \n \nAt 35, Swiss Federer is the oldest men's grand slam finalist since Ken Rosewall lost the US Open final in 1974 at the age of 39. \n \nNadal might be five years younger but has been on tour since his late teens and the effort required for his attritional playing style puts tremendous strain on his body. \n \nAnd while Federer has been able to rest up after his three-hour semi-final victory over Stan Wawrinka on Thursday, Nadal must recuperate as best he can after his epic five-hour victory over Grigor Dimitrov on Friday. \n \n\"That's what I'm going to try,\" the 14-times grand slam champion said. \"I did it in 2009. I am seven, eight years older.\" \n \nThat five-set 2009 victory over Federer earned Nadal his sole Australian Open crown and another would make him the only man in the open era apart from Roy Emerson to have won all four grand slams twice. \n \nFederer has four Australian Open titles but just a single French Open crown, his path to Roland Garros glory more often than not blocked by Nadal. \n \nImmediately after his semi-final, as he was finally able to ponder meeting his great rival, the 17-times grand slam champion suggested his 11-23 record against Nadal might have been in part due to them meeting on clay so often early in their careers. \n \nAfterwards, in his news conference, he was less candid, noting only that the pace of the Rod Laver Arena this year allowed him to be more aggressive. \n \n\"Now it's a different time,\" he said. \"A lot of time has gone by. I know this court allows me to play a certain game against Rafa that I cannot do on centre court at the French Open.\" \n \nNadal has a 6-2 edge over Federer in grand slam finals but few are making a call with any confidence over who will win Sunday's contest. \n \n\"I just know that two of the greatest players of tennis are going to square off on Sunday, and it's going to be a freakin' amazing match,\" Dimitrov said on Friday.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: tennis news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Live Australian Open 2017, Day 14: Roger Federer faces Rafael Nadal in final","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Firstpost.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"232003819","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"97"},"name":"Firstpost.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.firstpost.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204504609","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:05Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Tanner herself. \n   New Kids On The Block Brought All The Right Stuff  \nNew Kids On The Block are one of the O.G. boybands, and after over 30 years of performing together, the guys still have  the right stuff . NKOTB took the stage to perform hits like \u201cStep By Step,\u201d \u201cYou Got It (The Right Stuff),\u201d and more, and brought all of their amazing dance moves with them. And yes, we\u2019re talking about those classic steps you learned from watching their music videos. \n Also, the NKOTB fans were out in FULL FORCE. We did some things that were not intelligent and made it harder on ourselves. We just weren't disciplined. We were not a good defensive team tonight. If we're going to play defense like that, we're not going to win many games.\" \n \nRandolph bullied defenders in the post throughout the night and Gasol worked the Utah defense both inside and out, routinely hitting turnaround fade-away jumpers and going 4 of 5 on 3-pointers. \n \nThe Grizzlies took a 52-43 lead into halftime after a 13-2 run gave Memphis a 10-point lead. Randolph had his way with the Jazz post defenders and scored 10 of his 14 first-half points in the second quarter. \n \nThe Jazz shot just 26.3 percent from the field in the second quarter and never led in the second half. \n \nConley helped keep the Jazz at bay in the fourth quarter and finished with 23. \n \nRodney Hood led the Jazz with 20 points. \n \n\"Any time we have breakdowns, it's because we're not talking to each other and we're not helping each other out,\" Hood said. :I think that's the biggest thing. It's tough to lose when you know you can do better on that end. So, we've just got to get back to the drawing board.\" \n \n\"They have a lot of guys down there that are capable of putting up high numbers every night,\" said Jazz point guard George Hill, who had 16 points and 5 assists. \"They have good players and we've got to respect that, but a lot of breakdowns in coverages gave them some looks and they hit a lot of tough shots late in the shot clock also.\" \n \nQuin Snyder decided to rest starting power forward Derrick Favors. \n \nThe Jazz could have moved into the 4th seed in the Western Conference with a victory, but instead remain a half game back of the L.A. At present, Railways is running a pilot project for senior citizens who are entitled for rail concessions. \n \nThe concessional tickets cost the Railways about Rs 1,600 crore in 2015-16, with the bulk being accounted for senior citizens. \n \nAs per the government data, over 100 crore Aadhaar cards have been issued so for covering bulk of India's population. The government has decided to end the 92-year-old practice of presenting a separate Railway budget and merged it with the General Budget. Jaitley, according to sources, will contribute few pages of his Budget to programmes and schemes related to Indian Railways. \n \nAlthough there will be a single budget, the Railways will continue to have autonomy as commercial undertaking and the existing financial arrangement will remain. \n \nThe Railways is expected to get exemption from payment of dividend to the Union government, a move which will help strengthening its finances. \n \nThe organisation will also get budget support to meet part of its capital expenditure and will be allowed to raise extra budgetary resources. \n \nAccording to sources, Railways would continue to bear the expenditure on social and public service obligations. It is also expected that Jaitley will present a separate statement of budget estimates and demand for grants for Railways in the General Budget. There will also be a single Appropriation bill, including the estimates of Railways, to the Parliament. \n \n(PTI)","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Transportation industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Govt may make Aadhaar must for rail concession in Budget 2017","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"BTVI.in","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"608171604","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"BTVI.in","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Business"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.btvi.in"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204514557","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:11Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

mutual co-operation to defeat Islamic State and efforts in working together to achieve more peace throughout the world, including Syria. \n \nHowever, a White House official said sanctions imposed on Russia by President Trump\u2019s predecessor, Barack Obama, were not mentioned during the talks. \n \nBoth President Trump and President Putin are hopeful that after today\u2019s call the two sides {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396203144","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HEALTH CARE ACCESS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DENTISTRY","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ORAL HYGIENE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HEALTH CARE COSTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"WOMEN'S HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PREGNANCY & CHILDBIRTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DENTAL, MOUTH & JAW DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PERIODONTAL DISEASES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MEDICAID","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"94"},{"name":"ORAL HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CAVITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"DENTAL INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CHILDREN'S HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DIABETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"SPOKANE, WA, USA; UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"}],"wordCount":"472","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396203144&p=2kx&v=1&x=sc96rd7K85rKENWmGY13uA","id":"29396203144","content":"Washington state has done an admirable job of ensuring that children have access to dental care, but extending it to adults remains a sore point. \n \nApple Health (Medicaid) and programs like Access to Baby and Child Dentistry (ABCD) see to it that children can get exams, cleanings, fillings and extractions. As a result, the incidence of oral disease among young children has dropped. Advocates would like to do the same for adults, but the hurdles are significant. \n \nThe state\u2019s Medicaid reimbursement rate for adult dental care is one of the lowest in the nation, about 29 percent of what private insurers pay. In many instances, that\u2019s not enough to cover a dental office\u2019s costs, meaning they can take a loss for every Medicaid patient they see. \n \nLess than one-quarter of adults with Medicaid coverage have access to dental care. Those without access delay their care until it becomes an emergency. From 2011-14, the Legislature largely dropped adult dental coverage to balance budgets. Coverage has been restored, and now dentists are seeing a surge in people who had to postpone needed care. \n \nThe Washington Dental Services Foundation wants the state to increase the Medicaid reimbursement for the adult Medicaid population, but it also knows the Legislature is consumed with funding basic education this session. \n \nSo the foundation, a nonprofit supported by insurance provider Delta Dental, is making a small request of $1.5 million to help fund a pilot project aimed at covering pregnant women and adult diabetics by increasing their reimbursement rates. \n \nPregnant women are targeted as the next step to the foundation\u2019s efforts to allay unfounded fears (from patients and dentists) about pregnancy and dental care, and to encourage families to move up a child\u2019s first visit to age 1 rather than age 3. Women can transmit oral diseases to their babies before and after delivery, so they shouldn\u2019t avoid the dentist. Dental caries is the most common childhood disease and is totally preventable. \n \nDiabetes is targeted because it makes people more prone to gum disease, which makes it more difficult to control blood sugar. It\u2019s important that diabetics have regular dental care to forestall serious health consequences. \n \nSpokane would be a natural choice as one of the pilot sites, because of its historic commitment to expanding dental access. Plus, the region has relatively large Medicaid population. The ABCD program, which matches dentists to young children, was begun in Spokane. Ninety-eight of the area\u2019s 166 dentists are participants. \n \nIf this experiment were to succeed, the potential savings in health care costs would dwarf the initial expenditure, and the outcomes could be used to justify higher reimbursements for all adults under Medicaid. \n \nThe Legislature would be wise to give this a chance. \n \nTo respond to this editorial, visit www,spokesman.com and click on \u201cOpinion.\u201d \n \nPublished Jan. 29, 2017, midnight   in: ABCD, adults, Apple Health, Children, dental care, diabetes, medicaid, pregnant women, reimbursement","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Don\u2019t neglect dental coverage proposal - Sun, 29 Jan 2017 PST","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Spokane","zipCode":"99201","state":"Washington","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Spokane","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Spokesman-Review.com","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169685632","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4935"},"name":"Spokesman-Review.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://spokesmanreview.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204517001","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:14Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

INFLATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"PRICE CHANGES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CAMPAIGN FINANCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PHARMACEUTICALS INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LIBERALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DRUG PRICES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PRICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MEDICARE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"99"},{"name":"PRESCRIPTION DRUGS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"MIKE LEE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"53"},{"name":"BERNIE SANDERS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"RAND PAUL","domains":["PEO"],"score":"53"},{"name":"MARIA CANTWELL","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"GEORGE W BUSH","domains":["PEO"],"score":"56"},{"name":"PAUL RYAN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"TOM PRICE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"CHRIS COLLINS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"PATTY MURRAY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"565","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396203234&p=2kx&v=1&x=NHVpCVZ4UNU_sQfXbnmMOw","id":"29396203234","content":"Donald Trump has a chance to rally his core supporters as well as left-wing Democrats, wrapping himself in the populist flag to take on the politically powerful drug industry. \n \nHe is vowing to keep a campaign pledge to push legislation allowing Medicare to negotiate prescription drug prices, a practice currently prohibited by law. Proponents say this would reduce drug prices and Medicare costs for the federal government. Medicare pays for about 29 percent of prescription drugs in the U.S. and would have considerable leverage. \n \nTrump would be taking on the leaders of his own party, starting with House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wisconsin. Most Republicans have long argued that giving Medicare such power is tantamount to government price-setting, which ideologically they oppose and which they say would stifle innovation and research in the drug industry. Many of them receive huge campaign contributions from the industry\u2019s sizable political war chest. \n \nThere are arguments over the merits and effects, but the politics are clear cut. In a Kaiser Foundation poll last autumn, the public, by 82 percent to 17 percent, favored allowing the federal government to negotiate lower drug prices. Huge majorities say costly drug prices \u2013 in recent years they have risen about four times the rate of inflation \u2013 are a major concern. \n \nThese costs are felt by some of Trump\u2019s strongest supporters, non-college educated whites. And liberals, led by politicians like Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, champion a robust government role to keep drug prices down. \n \nIf Trump is serious, he\u2019ll have to do some heavy arm-twisting on Capitol Hill. Speaker Ryan says the current system is working \u201cextremely well,\u201d and suggests the president consult his designated Health and Human Services secretary, Tom Price. Like Ryan, Price is a small-government conservative skeptical of such interventions. \n \nThe clout of the drug industry shouldn\u2019t be underestimated. When the Medicare prescription-drug law was passed in 2003, the industry and its Republican allies, including President George W. Bush, insisted on a provision that explicitly bans Medicare from negotiating prices. \n \nDrug-industry interests made $18 million in political contributions to congressional candidates of both parties in the past election cycle. Even one of Trump\u2019s closest allies, Rep. Chris Collins, R-New York, opposes the idea of the cost negotiations. Collins, who is the president\u2019s go-to man on legislative relations, got $84,750 from the drug industry in the last election. Ryan received $326,949. \n \nThere was an instructive vote in the Senate this month on a closely related issue, allowing the importation of cheaper drugs from Canada. It failed 52 to 46. But it garnered the support of 10 Republicans, including deficit hawks like Rand Paul of Kentucky and Utah\u2019s Mike Lee. \n \nHowever, 13 Democrats (including Washington Sens. Patty Murray and Maria Cantwell), most of them beneficiaries of industry political contributions, voted against the measure. Subsequently, they have gotten a lot of flak from liberal groups, which especially have targeted Cory Booker of New Jersey. He received $49,830 from the industry in the last election. \n \nIf Trump goes all out on this issue, it will be near impossible for most of these Democrats to side with the industry over a Republican president whom they accuse of representing the interests of the rich. And, knowledgeable Congress watchers say, a number of Republicans, in the face of White House pressure and public opinion, would cave, too. \n \nAlbert Hunt is a Bloomberg View columnist. \n \nPublished Jan. 29, 2017, midnight   in: Donald Trump, drug prices, House Speaker Paul Ryan, Sen. Patty Murray. Sen. Maria Cantwell","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Albert R. Hunt"},"topics":[],"title":"Albert R. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29368854373","companies":[{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"DUS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"WPOB","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"},{"symbol":"GHC","primary":true,"name":"Graham Holdings Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US3846371041"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"66"},{"name":"SCANDALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"APPROVALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"GERMANY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"},{"name":"RONALD REAGAN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"761","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396203224&p=2kx&v=1&x=plf2aCK2AMQLleo6lV68AA","id":"29396203224","content":"All political leaders, presidents in particular, dream of using technology to avoid the media filter and speak directly to the American people. \n \nThomas Jefferson \u2013 both eloquent founder and appalling political hack \u2013 weaponized the pamphlet, commissioning scandalmonger James Callender to write a hit job on Alexander Hamilton. Warren Harding pioneered the political use of radio, which was perfected by Franklin Roosevelt, whose ambitions were aided by having a good radio voice. Not everyone was a fan of the medium. When a radio microphone was put in front of diplomat Elihu Root, he is said to have responded: \u201cTake that away. I can talk to a Democrat, but I cannot speak into a dead thing.\u201d \n \nJohn Kennedy\u2019s political appeal was unimaginable without televised images of his youth, vigor and physical grace. Ronald Reagan talked to the camera like an old, single-eyed friend. \n \nBut no president has really possessed the technical means to routinely avoid edited, moderated mass communication until now. President Trump holds his office, in part, because of his talent for Twitter. He has shown a remarkable ability to dominate the news cycle and redirect the national conversation in increments of 140 characters. For Trump, this medium is a living, snarling and hungry thing. \n \nMake no mistake: This is not only change, it is regression. I make this judgment both as a fogey and a former speechwriter. A presidential speech may be two or three thousand words, every one of them run through the staffing process (in which senior White House officials can comment), fact checked and approved by the president before delivery. A good presidential speech is the result of both thought and craft. A great presidential speech reflects literary, historical and moral inspiration and can speak far beyond its moment. \n \nI understand the usefulness of social media in aggregating flows of information that people trust, enjoy and need. It allows people to essentially be their own editors (the value of which is determined by the news literacy of the user). And some people have a remarkable knack for communicating in vivid fragments. Pope Francis (with 10 million Twitter followers) distributes little bits of wisdom and comfort like virtual communion wafers. Katy Perry (with more followers than the population of Germany) says, well, whatever it is that Katy Perry says. \n \nBut in politics, Twitter has dramatic limits and can become a disturbing substitute for disciplined thought. \n \nOne hundred and forty characters are suitable to expressing an impulse, but not an argument. It is the rhetorical equivalent of a groan, a shriek, a sneer or a burp. If reason and persuasion are what our politics lacks and needs, Twitter is not the answer. \n \nTrump\u2019s mastery and extensive use of Twitter are revealing in a way he does not intend. This is the only area in which Trump can be considered a great communicator. His stump speech was a disorganized, repetitive, unfocused mess. His inaugural speech was memorable only in ways \u2013 such as its dark, shrunken view of America itself \u2013 that deserve to be forgotten. His recent speech at the CIA was strangely inappropriate and offensive. So he often returns to the comfort zone of Twitter. He claims Hillary Clinton lost in a \u201clandslide,\u201d or goes after a specific news organization, or makes entirely unsubstantiated claims of voter fraud. \n \nSome feel that journalism would be better served by ignoring such shiny objects. But the shallowness of Trump\u2019s preferred form of communication indicates deeper things. His mind seems perfectly suited to a medium that rewards impulsiveness, that ignores fact-checking and that encourages incivility. Those are not generally the traits we hope for in a new president. \n \nAnd Trump\u2019s use of Twitter raises the prospect of a serious abuse of power. A private citizen with 22 million followers (as Trump has) can be a vindictive jerk, attacking the owner of the Cubs, the head of the United Steelworkers or a Gold Star family by name. A president with 22 million followers, including the shock troops of Internet bullying, can destroy an individual\u2019s life as surely as targeting by the FBI or the IRS. \n \nAt moments of frustration, Trump will be sorely tempted to attack specific people on Twitter. But a government official should not be allowed to take the reputation or peace of any citizen without due process. It is the president\u2019s job to enforce laws without distinction, not to choose specific men and women for harm. This would be the practice of personal rule, and a scary detour toward Putinism. \n \nMichael Gerson is a columnist for Washington Post Writers Group. \n \nPublished Jan. 29, 2017, midnight   in: Donald Trump, tweets, twitter","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Michael Gerson"},"topics":[],"title":"Michael Gerson: Trump\u2019s tweets are touch and go - Sun, 29 Jan 2017 PST","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Spokane","zipCode":"99201","state":"Washington","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Spokane","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Spokesman-Review.com","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169685632","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4935"},"name":"Spokesman-Review.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://spokesmanreview.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204518211","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JAY INSLEE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"68"}],"wordCount":"689","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396202905&p=2kx&v=1&x=kByLdtige7KEMIgvOGtTsg","id":"29396202905","content":"America\u2019s immigration system has been plunged into chaos and confusion in the wake of strict travel restrictions on people from seven Muslim-majority nations. \n \nPresident Trump\u2019s sweeping executive order for extreme vetting means no visas are being issued for 90 days to migrants or visitors from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. \n \nBut the ban is also affecting permanent, legal US citizens who were born in these countries. Those who were not on American soil when the decree came into effect are not able to re-enter for three months \u2013 separating them from their families and putting their jobs at risk. \n \nSome green card holders who were flying home to the US when the executive order was signed have been taken into custody at airports upon arrival \u2013 with dozens of immigration lawyers attempting to help the stranded. \n \nA judge has ruled those who have already landed in the US with valid visas can be temporarily allowed to stay in the country. \n \nAs of Saturday night, customs and border protection officials had denied entry to more than 170 people. \n \nOthers who were about to board flights back to America have been told they cannot travel \u2013 and the Homeland Security Department has been contacting airlines and recommending them to deny boarding to certain passengers. \n \nEnforcement of the executive order for those landing in the States has been described as patchy and disorganised, and some American airports have been more lenient than others. \n \nAccording to the executive order, exceptions can be made when it is in the national interest, but one federal law enforcement official said: It\u2019s unclear at this point what the threshold of the national interest is. \n \nThe International Air Transport Association has been told that the ban also applies to flight crew who are from one of the listed countries. \n \nProtests are taking place across the US \u2013 including airports in New York, Washington DC, Los Angeles, Chicago and Dallas. \n \nThe decree has also created uncertainty for refugees who were about to begin a new life in the States, as all resettlements have been suspended for at least 120 days while tougher vetting rules are established. Syrian refugees have been specifically barred from the US indefinitely. \n \nOne aid organisation said it knew of 2,000 refugees who had been scheduled to relocate to the US next week. \n \nNo refugees were on planes heading to America when the order came into force, but 350 people who had already begun their journeys are now stuck in Kenya. \n \nWashington Governor Jay Inslee, speaking at Sea-Tac Airport, condemned the chaos and cruelty of Mr Trump\u2019s policy \u2013 and warned it was provocative, incompetent, ineffective and damaging to the economy. \n \nBritish citizens who carry passports for one of the seven affected countries have also been caught up in the disruption. \n \nHamaseh Tayari, a Scottish vet who holds an Iranian passport, told the Guardian she has been left stranded in Costa Rica as her flight back to Glasgow was scheduled to go via New York. \n \nShe and her boyfriend now face the possibility of having to pay an extra £2,000 to fly to Madrid in order to get home. \n \nPresident Trump has said the executive order is a necessary step to stop radical Islamic terrorists from coming to the US \u2013 but stressed the decree is not a Muslim ban. \n \nHe has faced condemnation from leaders around the world, with Iran\u2019s Foreign Minister warning Tehran is going to stop issuing new visas to US citizens in retaliation to the ban. \n \nAmerican technology giants have also responded furiously to the immigration clampdown. \n \nApple chief executive Tim Cook said his company does not support the policy. In an apparent reference to its co-founder Steve Jobs, the son of a Syrian immigrant, Mr Cook said: Apple would not exist without immigration, let alone thrive and innovate the way we do. \n \nGoogle has urged its employees from the seven countries affected to cancel any travel plans outside the US. \n \nThe impact on foreign students is also unclear. Figures from the Homeland Security Department suggest that 17,000 students from the blacklisted countries were allowed into the US in 2015/16. \n \n(c) Sky News 2017: Trump\u2019s immigration ban sparks \u2018chaos and cruelty\u2019 worldwide  Comments  \ncomments","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Trump\u2019s immigration ban sparks \u2018chaos and cruelty\u2019 worldwide","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","county":"West Sussex","zipCode":"BN11","state":"England","countryCode":"GB","zipArea":"Worthing","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"MoreRadio","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"607988942","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2"},"name":"MoreRadio","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://moreradio.online"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204524794","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:13Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"prem","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396203344","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"MEDICAL RESEARCH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"51"},{"name":"HOTELS & MOTELS","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"SOCCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"TEMPORARY SHELTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"DOMESTIC VIOLENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PROGRAMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"WOMEN'S SHELTERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"783","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396203344&p=2kx&v=1&x=lFkc6pm17aiLS3yKd5aoRg","id":"29396203344","content":"I marched for her, but I also marched for him. \n \nMy 71-year-old mom, 9-year-old daughter and I descended on Washington, D.C., along with hundreds of thousands of others on Jan. 21. The sight of pink hats as far as the eye could see was awe-inspiring. I loved that we shared it as three generations, which will bind us tighter forever. \n \nA rich and vibrant discussion, mostly over social media, arose about the intention and meaning of the Women\u2019s March. The reasons are as diverse as the individuals who attended (not to mention the sea of colorful and creative signs they carried). \n \nI marched for her. Having no idea what to expect before the event, I was focused on imprinting a life memory in the mind of my daughter \u2013 one of the few crystal clear instances we remember within the haze of childhood. I hoped it would be etched into her very core and form the roots for the woman she grows into. There wouldn\u2019t be a specific moment in her life when she realized that her body is her own, or that she demanded equal rights, or that she believed that all humans are worthy of respect. Instead, it would be woven into her fabric, something that was always her. \n \nSince the march, when the flood of people submerged cities around the world, there have been critics who feel it was unnecessary, inappropriate or simply a waste of time. Facebook friends have decried it, saying it did not represent them or their views as a woman. One woman argued that a better way to support women\u2019s issues is to take all the money used for airplanes, hotels and taxis and donate it to cancer research or a domestic violence shelter. \n \nWhile we marched down Pennsylvania Avenue toward the White House chanting, \u201cTHIS is what democracy looks like!\u201d my mind swirled with the many reasons I was there. While those reasons remain crucial, what I hope my daughter takes away is this: You show up. There is value in just being there, surrounded by thousands of strangers united in presence. There are times that it is simply not enough to express your views on Facebook, or donate to an issue you care about or go to a board meeting. Sometimes you must show up. To stand in solidarity, to use your voice, to feel powerful. \n \nSometimes you refuse to accept that life is a pendulum swinging away from your beliefs. Sometimes you chant, \u201cHear my voice!\u201d And sometimes you march. \n \nI also marched for him. One of my own crystal clear memories is when my dad showed up for me. Big time. I was 11 years old and had just made the boys select soccer team until the coach told me that the city would not allow girls on the team. I remember the exact spot I was standing when he said those words. I also remember the exact spot I was standing when my dad said, \u201cThat is unacceptable.\u201d \n \nAfter threats of a lawsuit and weeks of negotiating, I was on that team. The message from my dad was clear: I will show up for you. That memory is impressed on my mind and woven into my fabric. \n \nPart of me hopes the Women\u2019s March is emblazoned on my daughter\u2019s mind. One of those moments she is proud to tell people about as an adult. The beginning of her strength, the day she found her voice. But another part of me hopes it will be a distant, faded memory of an archaic time when \u201cmy mom dragged me to D.C. because back then women were paid less than men.\u201d \n \nSometimes it is hard to show up. You are the only one and your voice can feel shaky and raw. Other times it is easy or joyful, like when you are surrounded by others with a common purpose fueling each other to make your singular voice louder. In many ways the Women\u2019s March was the latter. We were in the majority that day, which is both empowering and the easier path. No one telling you to be quiet or that you are wrong. That questioning feeling of \u201cam I doing the right thing?\u201d that can turn your face red and hot vanishes. I hope she will do both. Find support and unanimity with others but be willing to walk alone when it is uncomfortable or hard. \n \nSo I marched for her. But I also marched for him and the gift he gave me to just be there. Because that matters. \n \nGenevieve Mann is a supervising attorney and assistant professor at Gonzaga University School of Law. \n \nPublished Jan. 29, 2017, midnight   in: daughter, D.C., grandmother, mother, Washington, Women\u2019s March","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Genevieve Mann"},"topics":[],"title":"March was about the meaning of showing up - Sun, 29 Jan 2017 PST","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Spokane","zipCode":"99201","state":"Washington","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Spokane","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Spokesman-Review.com","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169685632","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4935"},"name":"Spokesman-Review.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://spokesmanreview.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204528343","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:17Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

going to come out and say it.\n\nI love February.\n\nThere's something about the energy of a fresh start, the invigorating cold air and crisp golden winter sun but without all the garden neediness and exertion of late spring and summer.\n\nOf course the RHS and garden shows will come out with a list of tasks you should be doing in the garden at this time of year but actually I think it's a good time to give the garden a break from meddling and just enjoy it.\n\nThis is where a little thoughtful laziness in autumn comes in hand.\n\nBy not cutting back the flowering stalks of last summer's herbaceous exuberance you get to appreciate the sculptural elements of plants.\n\nSome are better suited to this approach than others and generally it is the later flowering varieties that survive best.\n\nFor frost covered outdoor artworks look for plants that have rigid stems, bulky seed cones or a light airiness that can stand up to rain and wind.\n\nThose whose wild origins lie in wind-drenched prairies and grasslands such as coneflower (Echinacea) and sneezewort (Helenium), both from North America, produce large dark cones that show up well against lighter colours or grasses.\n\nThe small red, pink or white flowers of the Great Burnets (Sanguisorbas), especially the taller ones, look good as they darken to a mass of tiny suspended black buttons.\n\nYarrow (Achillea) is another plant of meadow origin whose dried, cloud-shaped umbels in winter provide a horizontal contrast to the verticals of say foxgloves or Veronicas.\n\nAny sea holly (Eryngium) is sculptural from the word go, but I think many of those with pale blue flowers in summer actually look better in winter.\n\nBut the granddaddy of all hoary floral delights has to be to the delicate spent flower clusters of fennel (Foeniculum vulgare), if only because the crystallised flowers are suspended so high up in the air.\n\nIn my front garden I use the feathery foliage and then bright yellow flowers of fennel to form an ideal backdrop to the rich, rust red cones of Helenium Moorheim Beauty.\n\nOrnamental grasses are also one of the highlights of the winter garden.\n\nRobust grasses that stand up to battering from wind and rain but retain much of their golden hue through winter, such as Stipa gigantea, Molinia varieties and Calamagrostis, look fabulous when covered in frost in the crisp winter sun.\n\nTo make these golden jewels stand out even more why not contrast them with the bright red and yellow branches of a dogwood (Cornus) or red-leaved evergreen plants such as Berberis, Phormium or Nandina domestica.\n\nTo this frosty combination you can add a few evergreens for additional structure.\n\nThe strappy leaves of Crocosmia, Phormium or Libertia grandiflora will give further shape.\n\nAnd there is a certain appeal in the repeated rounded forms of topiarised box, yew or beech \u2013 if placed in a pattern on open ground they can look a secret gathering of plants in some parallel world.\n\nHave fun with winter colour but give your garden a rest in February.\n\nIt's sleeping through the bitter cold of winter .. much like the rest of us would like to.\n\nRobert Kennett can be contacted on 07968 113546 or via his website robertkennett.co.uk.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Gardening blog: Robert Kennett on the delights {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:02:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396203697","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BOTTLED WATER","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LANDFILLS","domains":["IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"PLASTIC BOTTLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTAL & WILDLIFE ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"WILDLIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BEACHES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"USED MERCHANDISE STORES","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"MOBILE APPLICATIONS","domains":["IND"],"score":"60"},{"name":"MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"441","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396203697&p=2kx&v=1&x=sTECMhZAFNqinV2f-JhFbw","id":"29396203697","content":"Participating businesses will refill customers' re-useable bottles for free, in the hope that more people will be encouraged to carry re-useable bottles rather than reaching for bottled water each time they're thirsty.\n\nThe project is being run locally by Litter Free Coast and Sea which hopes it will change people's habits, as Project Co-Ordinator Natalie Poulter explains: \"Every time somebody refills rather than buying a new bottle from a shop or café, one fewer bottle runs the risk of ending up as either litter or going to landfill.\n\n\"Single use plastic water bottles are one of the most frequently found items of litter on our beaches here in Dorset, so it's important to take as many out of circulation as possible.\n\n\"We hope that by encouraging businesses to offer this simple service, and encouraging customers to take it up, it will become the norm to invest in a bottle you love and take it everywhere with you.\n\n\"Participating businesses have told us it makes perfect sense to offer free tap water to their customers, and many are keen to promote something they're doing already. The refills are totally free with no pressure to buy anything else, but we find often people buy a coffee or cake at the same time.\n\n\"Refill not only saves customers money but, for a café, it can also cut down rubbish and recycling bills. Most importantly it means they can show that they're a friendly business that cares about their customers and local environment, which is increasingly important in building customer loyalty.\"\n\nWhilst most businesses involved are cafes and coffee shops, there are some more unusual ones: a couple of charity shops, a community centre and even an estate agency have agreed to join the scheme.\n\n#RefillDorset is also supported by Dorset Wildlife Trust, which has all its visitor centres as refill stations and sells refillable bottles at Kimmeridge and Chesil Beach.\n\nJulie Hatcher, Dorset Wildlife Trust's Marine Awareness Officer said: \"Plastic drink bottles and lids are among the commonest types of litter we find on beaches. The Refill campaign aims to tackle this problem at its source and offer people a healthier and cheaper option at the same time.\n\n\"All Dorset Wildlife Trust's centres are happy to offer free tap water refills. Just call in and ask.\"\n\nEach business proudly displays a 'Refill here' blue sticker in their window to show customers it's ok to ask. At that time, many other enterprises also tried to seek opportunities from overseas markets, but they did not move ahead and waited to see if FPT could succeed with its business before making decisions. \n\nFive to eight years later, some companies begin exploiting foreign markets. \n \nRelating the story, Binh said if everyone tries to \u2018play safe\u2019, they will waste time and miss great opportunities. Foreign markets have helped FPT grow rapidly, as they are vast markets which bring a high growth rate of hundreds of percent. \n FPT and Viettel, two large telecom and IT corporations, which have reaped initial successes from making outward investments, say they will join forces with other Vietnamese businesses to exploit foreign markets.  \nIn the last few years, FPT has been providing IT and telecom services to Cambodia, Bangladesh and Myanmar to get money to offset decreases in the domestic market. \n\nNguyen Trung Chinh, president of CMC, said foreign markets brought the 200 percent growth rate to CMC last year and he believes the growth rate would be even more satisfactory in the time to come. \n\nAccording to Viettel\u2019s CEO Nguyen Manh Hung, people should not think that business should grow in the domestic market first before trying to reach foreign markets, because opportunities may be missed. \n\n\u201cBusinesses can develop the domestic and foreign markets just like walking on two feet,\u201d he said. \u201cThe domestic market will get saturated, and therefore, foreign markets will be the playing fields for enterprises that want to expand.\" \n\nViettel\u2019s success in overseas markets has inspired many other enterprises. KINGDOM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"GEORGIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"563","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396204054&p=2kx&v=1&x=iut3OBMrk5f_6GqUzous0g","id":"29396204054","content":"Since going public in March 2012, shares of BGEO Group  (LSE: BGEO) have returned a whopping 175% while those of banking behemoth Barclays  (LSE: BARC) have lost 10% in the same time frame. But now that Barclays is finally making tentative progress towards solving the problems that have plagued it since the Financial Crisis, can shares of the British bank catch up to those of the much smaller BGEO group? \n \nNow on the face of it, comparing BGEO, the holding company for Bank of Georgia, and Barclays seems a bit like comparing apples and oranges. However, a retail bank with low operating costs, a very profitable investment bank, no legacy misconduct issues and stunning profitability shows that Bank of Georgia is what Barclays should aspire to be. And the phenomenal returns of BGEO over the past five years show exactly why investors should cheer for this. \n \nThe driving forces behind its success have been steady mid-single-digit GDP growth for the past decade in Georgia, and a successful programme of taking market share from competitors by offering best-in-class retail banking capabilities. The bank now has around 30% market share in the country and growing scale has allowed it to keep operating costs much lower than comparable British banks. In first nine months of 2016, Bank of Georgia's cost-to-income ratio was a stunningly low 37.7%, while return on average equity was a very impressive 22.8%. \n  \nThis high level of profitability combined with top line growth boosted profits by 57.9% year-on-year to £112.2m in the first three quarters of 2016. And with return on equity steadily rising and the bank targeting 20% annual growth in the retail operation over the medium term, there's plenty of potential future profit growth. This is great news for investors as the bank's policy of returning 50% of profits in dividends means analysts are pencilling in a 3.5% dividend yield in the year ahead. BGEO shares are very pricey at 2.4 times book value, but if Bank of Georgia continues to impress, this lofty valuation could make sense in the long term. \n Cheap for a reason?  \nMeanwhile, shares of Barclays are still trading well below their tangible book value at 0.78. There's good reason for this. Return on tangible equity (RoTE) reduced year-on-year in the first nine months of 2016, from 5.8% to 4.4%, as the £44bn of non-core bad assets ran up a staggering £1.4bn loss. While management is making progress in divesting these assets, it's slow going and they will continue to be a drag on the overall group for some time to come. \n \nOn the bright side, core operations excluding exceptional items RoTE was a much better 10.7% in the period, driven by solid returns from the UK retail bank and stunning 21.3% RoTE from credit card operations. Unfortunately, fantastic returns from Barclaycard continue to be obscured by the billions of bad assets on the books as well as the massive transsatlantic investment bank whose RoTE in the period was a meagre 8.7%. \n \nWith billions of bad assets still to be sold, a management team clinging to an investment bank whose returns lag its cost of capital, a stubbornly high cost-to-income ratio of 73%, and dividends slashed, I'd bet on Barclays' shares continuing to underperform BGEO's in the coming years. \n \nIan Pierce has no position in any shares mentioned. The Motley Fool UK has recommended Barclays.
